text: And Lamech married two women, one named Adah and the other Zillah.

translation_challenges.note: In this context, the phrase **took for himself** is a common expression that means “married.” Consider whether or not your language has a similar expression. Alternate translation: [Then Lamech grew up, and he chose two women to be his wives] or [When Lamech grew up, he married two women]

text: Adah gave birth to Jabal; he was the father of those who dwell in tents and raise livestock.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [a son whose name was Jabal]
Alternate translation: [who was] or [who grew up and became]

The phrase **father of** is used here as a common expression that means Jabal was the first person to do these things. He originated this way of living, and many people after him followed his example. Alternate translation: [the first of all people who]

text: And his brother’s name was Jubal; he was the father of all who play the harp and flute.

translation_challenges.note: Jubal was probably younger than Jabal. See how you translated **brother** in verse [4:2](../04/02.md). Alternate translation: [Jabal had a brother named Jubal]
Alternate translation: [who was] or [He grew up and became]
See how you translated a similar phrase in verse [4:20](../04/20.md). Alternate translation: [the ancestor of all people who]
Alternate translation: [play musical instruments called lyres and pipes] or [play stringed instruments and wind instruments]

text: And Zillah gave birth to Tubal-cain, a forger of every implement of bronze and iron. And the sister of Tubal-cain was Naamah.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [also became pregnant and gave birth to a son, and they named him]
Be consistent with how you spell this name both times in verse [4:22](../04/22.md). Alternate translation: [Tubal-Cain] or [Tubal-cain] or [Tubalcain]

It is probably implied from [verses 20-21](../04/20.md) that Tubal Cain, like his brothers, was the father or first of all those who had this skill. Alternate translation: [He was the first person to forge] or [He was the first blacksmith, and he forged] or [He was the first of all people who forge]

The word **tools** that is used here in the Hebrew text is general and can include farming tools and weapons and other things that are made out of metal. Alternate translation: [all kinds of tools and other things out of brass and iron] or [all kinds of brass and iron things]

text: Then Lamech said to his wives: “Adah and Zillah, hear my voice; wives of Lamech, listen to my speech. For I have slain a man for wounding me, a young man for striking me.

translation_challenges.note: Consider what is the best way in your language to introduce this new event. Alternate translation: [One time, Lamech said proudly] or [One day, Lamech boasted]
Be consistent with how you spelled these names in verses [4:19–20](../04/19.md), [4:22–23](../04/22.md).

The phrase **my voice** refers here to the words being said. Consider what is the best way to translate this figure of speech in your language. Alternate translation: [listen to what I am going to tell you]

This clause forms a parallelism, use of two phrases mean basically the same thing, with the previous clause and emphasizes what Lamech says next. Also, consider whether or not your language has an expression that is similar to **give ear to**. Alternate translation: [My wives, listen to me carefully]

This could mean: (1) that Lamech killed a young man who bruised him. Alternate translation: [I killed a man for wounding me; he was a young man who bruised me!] or [I killed a young man for wounding me! In fact, I killed that man just because he injured me!]; (2) that Lamech killed two a man who wounded him and also a man who bruised him. Alternate translation: [I killed a man for wounding me, and I also killed a young man for bruising me] or [A man wounded me, so I killed him. A young man bruised me, so I killed him too!]

text: If Cain is avenged sevenfold, then Lamech seventy-sevenfold.”

translation_challenges.note: Consider what is the best way to translate this passive clause in your language. Alternate translation: [Since God has promised to avenge Cain seven times, then] or [Cain is avenged by God seven times, but]

Lamech is bragging in [verses 23](../04/23.md) and [24](../04/24.md) about how severely he avenges himself. He is not saying that God will avenge him more than he will avenge Cain. Also, each translation team needs to decide how they will handle numbers in the Hebrew text so that readers will not confuse those numbers with verse numbers. For example, it may be best to use words for single and double-digit numbers in the text. Be consistent with how you spelled the name **Lamech** in [verses 18-19](../04/18.md), [23-24](../04/23.md). Alternate translation: [I, Lamech avenge myself seventy-seven times!] or [I avenge myself 77 times!]

text: And Adam again had relations with his wife, and she gave birth to a son and named him Seth, saying, “God has granted me another seed in place of Abel, since Cain killed him.”

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated the common expression **knew** in verses [4:1](../04/01.md) and [4:17](../04/17.md). Alternate translation: [Then Adam slept with his wife Eve again]
Alternate translation: [so that she conceived and had a son] or [with the result that she became pregnant and gave birth to a son]
See how you translated a similar phrase in [3:20](../03/20.md). Alternate translation: [and she gave him the name]

What follows is a direct quote of what Eve said that gave Seth his name. Make sure that is clear in your language. Alternate translation: [She named him that because when he was born, she had exclaimed]

If you include the meaning of Seth’s name in your translation or in a footnote, make sure it matches the way you translate **appointed** here, so that it is clear why he was given that name. Alternate translation: [God has given to me]

For some languages it is necessary to put this phrase first in this clause so that events are in the order that they happened. Alternate translation: [Since Cain killed Abel, God granted me another child to replace him]

text: And to Seth also a son was born, and he called him Enosh. At that time men began to call upon the name of the LORD.

translation_challenges.note: The word order in the Hebrew text here emphasizes Seth. Alternate translation: [Later on, Seth also had a son]
Alternate translation: [At that time] or [That is when]

text: This is the book of the generations of Adam. In the day that God created man, He made him in His own likeness.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [What follows is]
Alternate translation: [about Adam and his descendants:]

See how you translated **created** in Genesis [1:1](../01/01.md), [1:27](../01/27.md); [2:4](../02/04.md), and “man” in Genesis [1:26–27](../01/26.md). Alternate translation: [On the day that God made human beings, he made them]
God created mankind to be like himself in certain ways, but not to be exactly like him in every way (Genesis [1:26–27](../01/26.md)). Alternate translation: [in his own likeness]

text: Male and female He created them, and He blessed them. And in the day they were created, He called them “man.”

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated this clause in Genesis [1:27](../01/27.md).
See how you translated the phrase “called … name” in Genesis [4:17](../04/17.md) and [4:25,](../04/25.md). Alternate translation: [and called them]
Be consistent here with how you translated this term in verse [5:1](../05/01.md).

For some languages, it is clearer or more natural to put this clause earlier in this verse. Alternate translation: [and on the same day that they were created, he blessed them and called them human beings]

text: When Adam was 130 years old, he had a son in his own likeness, after his own image; and he named him Seth.

translation_challenges.note: Each translation team needs to decide how they are going to write large numbers in the Bible. Many teams use numerals, for example, **130** here in [verse 3](../05/03.md), especially if the target language has a complicated counting system. Other teams prefer to use words, for example, “one hundred and thirty” here. Be consistent in what you do throughout your translation. Alternate translation: [When Adam had lived 130 years, he had a son] or [When Adam was 130 years old, he fathered a son]

These two phrases have similar meanings and emphasize that Seth was similar to Adam in many ways. See how you translated similar phrases in Genesis [1:26](../01/26.md). Alternate translation: [who was a human being like himself and looked like him]

text: And after he had become the father of Seth, Adam lived 800 years and had other sons and daughters.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [After he had Seth, he lived] or [After Seth was born, Adam lived]

For some languages, it may be more natural to change the clause order of this sentence and say, “Adam lived 800 more years after Seth was born …” Do what is best in your language throughout this chapter. Alternate translation: [800 more years]

This clause probably refers to all the other children that Adam had, including those who were born before and after Seth was born. Alternate translation: [and he also had] or [Adam also had] or [He was also the father of]

text: So Adam lived a total of 930 years, and then he died.
When Seth was 105 years old, he became the father of Enosh.

translation_challenges.note: The events in [verse 6](../05/06.md) happened before Adam died ([verse 5](../05/05.md)). So if you use a conjunction here, make sure your translation does not sound like [verse 6](../05/06.md) happened after Adam died. Alternate translation: [After Seth had lived 105 years] or [After Seth was 105 years old]

You could make it explicit in your translation or in a footnote that Enosh was a son. The same thing is true for the rest of the children whose births are mentioned in this chapter (who were all sons). Alternate translation: [he fathered a son named Enosh] or [he had a son they named Enosh] or [he had a son whose name was Enosh]

text: And after he had become the father of Enosh, Seth lived 807 years and had other sons and daughters.

translation_challenges.note: In fact, throughout [chapter 5](../05/01.md), make sure it is clear in your translation whom each pronoun refers to. Alternate translation: [After he had Enosh, he lived] or [After Enosh was born, Seth lived]
Alternate translation: [807 more years]
See how you translated this phrase and the following one in [verse 4](../05/04.md). Alternate translation: [and he also had] or [Seth also had] or [He was also the father of]

text: So Seth lived a total of 912 years, and then he died.
When Enosh was 90 years old, he became the father of Kenan.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated the beginning of a similar new paragraph in this genealogy at [verse 6](../05/06.md). Alternate translation: [After Enosh had lived 90 years] or [After Enosh was 90 years old]

text: And after he had become the father of Kenan, Enosh lived 815 years and had other sons and daughters.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated a similar sentence in verse [5:7](../05/07.md), and see the notes about that there. Alternate translation: [After he had Kenan, he lived] or [After Kenan was born, Enosh lived]
Alternate translation: [815 more years]
Alternate translation: [and he also had] or [Enosh also had] or [He was also the father of]

text: So Enosh lived a total of 905 years, and then he died.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [before he died]

text: When Kenan was 70 years old, he became the father of Mahalalel.

translation_challenges.note: Throughout this chapter, be consistent with how you have decided to handle numbers in the Bible. For example, many translation teams use words for single and double-digit numbers, but use numerals for larger numbers. This strategy helps prevent confusion with verse numbers. This is especially true in translations that use a large font size for verse numbers so that people doing group Bible study can easily be in the same verse together. Alternate translation: [After Kenan had lived seventy years] or [After Kenan was seventy years old]

text: And after he had become the father of Mahalalel, Kenan lived 840 years and had other sons and daughters.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [After Kenan had Mahalalel, he lived] or [After Mahalalel was born, Kenan lived]
Alternate translation: [840 more years]
Consider what is the best way in your language to refer to Kenan at this point in the paragraph. Alternate translation: [and he also had] or [Kenan also had] or [He was also the father of]

text: So Kenan lived a total of 910 years, and then he died.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [before he died]

text: When Mahalalel was 65 years old, he became the father of Jared.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [After Mahalalel had lived 65 years] or [After Mahalalel was 65 years old]

text: And after he had become the father of Jared, Mahalalel lived 830 years and had other sons and daughters.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [After he had Jared, he lived] or [After Jared was born, Mahalalel lived]
Alternate translation: [830 more years]
Alternate translation: [and he also had] or [He also fathered] or [He was also the father of]

text: So Mahalalel lived a total of 895 years, and then he died.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [before he died]

text: When Jared was 162 years old, he became the father of Enoch.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [After Jared had lived 162 years] or [After Jared was 162 years old]

text: And after he had become the father of Enoch, Jared lived 800 years and had other sons and daughters.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [After Jared had Enoch, he lived] or [After Enoch was born, Jared lived]
Alternate translation: [800 more years]
Consider what is the best way in your language to refer to Jared at this point in the paragraph. Alternate translation: [and he also had] or [Jared also had] or [He was also the father of]

text: So Jared lived a total of 962 years, and then he died.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [before he died]

text: When Enoch was 65 years old, he became the father of Methuselah.

translation_challenges.note: Consider again how you translated double-digit numbers in [verses 9](../05/09.md), [12](../05/12.md), [15](../05/15.md), [21](../05/21.md). Alternate translation: [After Enoch had lived 65 years] or [After Enoch was 65 years old]

text: And after he had become the father of Methuselah, Enoch walked with God 300 years and had other sons and daughters.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [After he had Methuselah] or [After Methuselah was born]

The phrase **walked with** is used here as a common expression that means “lived in a close relationship with.” Consider whether or not you have a similar expression in your language. Alternate translation: [Enoch lived faithfully with God] or [Enoch lived in a faithful relationship with God]
Alternate translation: [for 300 more years]
Alternate translation: [and he also had] or [Enoch also had] or [He was also the father of]

text: So Enoch lived a total of 365 years.

translation_challenges.note: Make sure that the name **Enoch** is spelled consistently in your translation of [verses 18-19](../05/18.md), [21-24](../05/21.md). Alternate translation: [So he lived a total of 365 years] or [All together he lived 365 years]

text: Enoch walked with God, and then he was no more, because God had taken him away.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [All his life Enoch lived in a faithful relationship with God]
Alternate translation: [and suddenly he was not on earth anymore] or [and he suddenly disappeared from earth]
It may be more natural to put this clause before the previous clause and say, “… God took him away to be with him, so he was suddenly no longer on earth.”

text: When Methuselah was 187 years old, he became the father of Lamech.

translation_challenges.note: Consider again how you translated verses in this chapter that are similar in structure to this verse; see [verses 6](../05/06.md), [9](../05/09.md), [12](../05/12.md), [15](../05/15.md), [18](../05/18.md), [21](../05/21.md), [25](../05/25.md), and part of [verses 3](../05/03.md) and [28](../05/28.md), and see the note about this at [verse 6](../05/06.md). Alternate translation: [After Methuselah had lived 187 years] or [After Methuselah was 187 years old]

text: And after he had become the father of Lamech, Methuselah lived 782 years and had other sons and daughters.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [After he had Lamech, he lived] or [After Lamech was born, Methuselah lived]
Alternate translation: [782 more years]
Consider what is the best way in your language to refer to Methuselah at this point in the paragraph. Alternate translation: [and he also had] or [He also fathered] or [He was also the father of]

text: So Methuselah lived a total of 969 years, and then he died.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation, without the preceding comma: [before he died]

text: When Lamech was 182 years old, he had a son.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [After Lamech had lived 182 years] or [After Lamech was 182 years old]

text: And he named him Noah, saying, “May this one comfort us in the labor and toil of our hands caused by the ground that the LORD has cursed.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [whom he named]
If you include the meaning of Noah’s name in your translation or in a footnote, make sure it matches what Lamech says about him in the following quote so that it is clear why he was given that name.
What Lamech says next is the reason why he named his son Noah. Make sure that is clear in your translation. Alternate translation: [He named him that because he had said about him]
Alternate translation: [This son will relieve us] or [This son will give us relief]

These two phrases have similar meanings and emphasize how difficult the work was. Consider what is the best way to communicate that in your language. Alternate translation: [from the difficult labor and work we have to do with our hands] or [from the agonizing work that we have to do]
Alternate translation: [as we farm the ground that Yahweh has cursed]

text: And after he had become the father of Noah, Lamech lived 595 years and had other sons and daughters.

translation_challenges.note: Consider again how you translated verses in this chapter that are similar in structure to this verse; see [verses 7](../05/07.md), [10](../05/10.md), [13](../05/13.md), [16](../05/16.md), [19](../05/19.md), [26](../05/26.md), [30](../05/30.md), and part of [verses 4](../05/04.md) and [22](../05/22.md). Alternate translation: [After he fathered Noah, he lived] or [After Noah was born, Lamech lived]
Alternate translation: [595 more years]
Alternate translation: [and he also had] or [Lamech also had] or [He was also the father of]

text: So Lamech lived a total of 777 years, and then he died.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [before he died]

text: After Noah was 500 years old, he became the father of Shem, Ham, and Japheth.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **a son of 500 years** is a common expression that means “was 500 years old.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And Noah saw his 500th year] or [Noah turned 500 years old]
Noah’s sons were not triplets, but were born in different years after Noah was 500 years old. The way you translate this verse should allow for that meaning.

text: Now when men began to multiply on the face of the earth and daughters were born to them,

translation_challenges.note: The author is using **And it happened** to describe something that was ongoing. This provides the background for other events he will describe that began to happen during this time. Connect this clause to the story in a way that makes it clear in your language that this clause is describing something that was ongoing in the background. \nThe events in Genesis [6:1–2](../06/01.md) started happening long before the events in [5:32](../05/32.md), so the way your translation begins this verse should allow for that meaning and not begin with a sequence word like “Then.”
Alternate translation: [that as]
See how you translated **mankind** in Genesis [5:1–2](../05/01.md). Alternate translation: [human beings]
Alternate translation: [began to increase in number] or [began to be more numerous]
Alternate translation: [throughout the world]
Alternate translation: [and they were having many daughters]

text: the sons of God saw that the daughters of men were beautiful, and they took as wives whomever they chose.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then those girls grew up, and the sons of God saw]
Alternate translation: [saw that the daughters of human beings were beautiful] or [saw that those young women were beautiful] or [saw that they were very beautiful]
Alternate translation: [so they married any of them that they wanted to marry]

text: So the LORD said, “My Spirit will not contend with man forever, for he is mortal; his days shall be 120 years.”

translation_challenges.note: The implication is that Yahweh is speaking to himself. Only make implied information explicit in your translation if it is necessary to prevent wrong meaning or if your language’s grammar requires it so that your translation is easier to read and understand. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [So Yahweh said to himself]

The words **My Spirit** could mean: (1) God is speaking of his spirit or saying “I,” which is a way of God referring to himself (Genesis [1:2](../01/02.md) is similar) (2) that God is referring to his breath that gives life (as in Genesis [2:71](../02/71.md)). If the text is not translated literally, the literal text should be put in a footnote.

The phrase **will not strive with mankind forever** could mean: (1) that God will not contend with human beings forever. Alternate translation: [will not put up with human beings forever] or (2) that God will not remain with human beings forever. Alternate translation: [will not dwell among humans forever] The interpretation that is not used in your translation could be put in a footnote.

The word **flesh** is used here as a common expression that means human beings are “mortal” (that is, their bodies will die) and that they are “sinful.” The two meanings are interrelated since it is because of sin that their bodies die. In this context, the focus is on their corrupt behavior, which is the reason God will send a flood. Alternate translation: [because they are very sinful] or [because they are only sinful mortals]

This sentence could mean: (1) that mankind will have 120 years to repent. Alternate translation: [I will give them 120 years to repent]; (2) that 120 years will be the maximum lifespan. Alternate translation: [From now on, they will have no longer than 120 years.] The first interpretation seems to best fit the context here of God announcing his plan to judge mankind for their sin ([verse 7](../06/07.md)). This would mean that Noah was 480 years old when God said this (about 20 years before he started having sons; Genesis [5:32](../05/32.md)), since the flood came when he was 600 years old (Genesis [7:6](../07/06.md)); you could put some of that information in a footnote. The second interpretation does not fit with the fact that after God said this, many people lived much longer than 120 years, so it does not seem likely that length of life was his meaning here.

text: The Nephilim were on the earth in those days—and afterward as well—when the sons of God had relations with the daughters of men. And they bore them children who became the mighty men of old, men of renown.

translation_challenges.note: Most translations transliterate (borrow or copy) the Hebrew word **Nephilim** here, treating it as a name. The word means “fallen ones” and probably refers to their fallen (sinful) spiritual state. The Nephilim were the descendants of the sons of God and the daughters of mankind. The only other time in the Bible that the Nephilim are mentioned is centuries later in [Numbers 13:32–33](../../num/13/32.md), where they are identified as evil giants. Based on that, some translations translate “the Nephilim” as “giants” here in Genesis [6:4](../06/04.md). Alternate translation: [Giants called the Nephilim] or [Giants]
It may be more natural to put this time phrase first in [verse 4](../06/04.md) and say, “During that time there were Nephilim living on the earth, when …”
Alternate translation: [That was when]
Be consistent here with how you translated this phrase in verse [6:2](../06/02.md), and see the important note about that there. Alternate translation: [angels] or [supernatural beings]

Translate this common expression in a way that is polite and will not shame or embarrass people when this verse is read aloud in public. See how you translated a similar expression (“knew”) in Genesis [4:1](../04/01.md), [4:17](../04/17.md) and [4:25](../04/25.md). Alternate translation: [slept with] or [had sexual relations with]
See how you translated this phrase in verse [6:2](../06/02.md). Alternate translation: [human women]
Make sure it is clear in your translation who is being referred to here. Alternate translation: [Those children grew up and were the Nephilim, who were]
Alternate translation: [the powerful men] or [heroes]
Alternate translation: [who lived a long time ago] or [who lived many years ago]

For some languages it may be more natural to put this phrase earlier in this sentence and say, “They were the mighty men of renown who were from long ago.” or “They were the famous mighty men who lived a long time ago.” Alternate translation: [who were famous men]

text: Then the LORD saw that the wickedness of man was great upon the earth, and that every inclination of the thoughts of his heart was altogether evil all the time.

translation_challenges.note: The verb **saw** is used here as a common expression. Consider whether your language has a similar common expression that would fit well here. Alternate translation: [Yahweh knew] or [Yahweh was aware]

In Hebrew culture the heart is considered the center of thoughts and desires. Consider whether your language has a similar common expression. Alternate translation: [and that every desire they had in their minds] or [and that everything they thought about and wanted]
Alternate translation: [constantly]

text: And the LORD regretted that He had made man on the earth, and He was grieved in His heart.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **mankind** in verses [6:1. 3, and 5](../06/01.md), and consider whether or not it is best to use a pronoun (“them”) here in your language. Alternate translation: [that he had created them] or [that he had created human beings]
Consider whether your language has a similar common expression that would fit well here. Alternate translation: [and his heart was filled with pain] or [and he was very sad]

text: So the LORD said, “I will blot out man, whom I have created, from the face of the earth—every man and beast and crawling creature and bird of the air—for I am grieved that I have made them.”

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated this phrase in [verse 3](../06/03.md). Also make sure that the way you begin [verse 7](../06/07.md) fits well with the way you begin [verse 6](../06/06.md). The implication is that Yahweh is speaking to himself. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [Then he said to himself]
Consider whether your language has a similar common expression that would fit well here. Alternate translation: [I will wash away] or [I will blot out]
Alternate translation: [all the human beings whom I created, from the surface of the earth]
Alternate translation: [In fact, I will destroy not just all the people, but also all the animals]
Alternate translation: [and the creatures that move on the ground]

It might seem that the expression **birds of the sky** contains extra information that would be unnatural to express in your language. If so, you can shorten it. Alternate translation: [and all the birds]
See how you translated “was sorry” or “regretted” in verse [6:6](../06/06.md). Alternate translation: [because I am sad]
Alternate translation: [that I ever created them]

text: Noah, however, found favor in the eyes of the LORD.

translation_challenges.note: The common expression **found favor** means “pleased someone.” And the common expression **in the eyes of** refers to someone’s opinion about something or someone. Consider whether your language has similar expressions that work well here or whether it is better to translate this sentence without a common expression. Alternate translation: [But Noah pleased God] or [However, Yahweh was pleased with Noah]

text: This is the account of Noah. Noah was a righteous man, blameless in his generation; Noah walked with God.

translation_challenges.note: Some of Noah’s history has already been given in Genesis [5:29](../05/29.md), [32](../05/32.md), and [6:8](../06/08.md). What follows tells more about him. Alternate translation: [This is more of the record of Noah and his family:] or [What follows tells more about Noah and his family:]
Consider whether it is better in your language to use a noun or a pronoun here to refer to Noah.
Alternate translation: [a good man]

This sentence could mean: (1) Among his contemporaries, he alone was faultless in God’s eyes. Alternate translation: [Of all the people living at that time, Noah was the only one whom God considered blameless] or (2) He had a spotless reputation among his contemporaries. The phrase **without blemish** is often used in the Bible to describe animals that have no defects. Here it is used as a common expression meaning that Noah was blameless or faultless in an ethical or moral sense or that he had good integrity, but it does not mean that he was totally sinless. Consider whether your language has a similar common expression that would work well here.
See how you translated this common expression in [5:22, 24](../05/22.md). Alternate translation: [and he walked closely with God] or [and he lived in a faithful relationship with God]

text: And Noah had three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.

translation_challenges.note: The fact that Noah fathered these three sons was already mentioned in Genesis [5:32](../05/32.md). Make sure that the way you begin this verse in your translation does not sound like he fathered these sons a second time. Alternate translation: [Eventually he had] or [And as mentioned before, he had]
Alternate translation: [three sons, namely Shem, Ham, and Japheth]

text: Now the earth was corrupt in the sight of God, and full of violence.

translation_challenges.note: The phrase **the earth** is often used in the Bible to refer to all the people on the earth. Consider whether your language can do the same thing, or whether it is necessary to make that implied information explicit. Alternate translation: [Now the people of the earth had become corrupt]

The author uses two phrases which mean basically the same thing in order to emphasize how evil the people on the earth had become. The two clauses are different enough from each other that, if possible, it is best to keep both of them in your translation. Also be consistent with how you translated **the earth** earlier in this verse. Alternate translation: [and they had filled the earth with their destructive brutality] or [and all over the earth they were forcefully doing harm]

text: And God looked upon the earth and saw that it was corrupt; for all living creatures on the earth had corrupted their ways.

translation_challenges.note: Consider whether or not it is best in your language to begin this sentence with a conjunction.

See how you translated “corrupt” and **the earth** in verse [6:11](../06/11.md). Alternate translation: [that everyone on the earth was very wicked] or [how dishonest everyone on the earth had become]
The phrase **all flesh** refers here to all people and probably implies that people are mortal ([verse 3](../06/03.md)). Alternate translation: [because everyone living on earth]
Alternate translation: [were living wicked lives] or [were continually doing wicked things]

text: Then God said to Noah, “The end of all living creatures has come before Me, because through them the earth is full of violence. Now behold, I will destroy both them and the earth.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then God said to Noah]
Be consistent here with how you translated **flesh** in [verse 12](../06/12.md). Alternate translation: [I have decided to put an end to all human beings] or [I am going to destroy all mortals]

See how you translated **violence** in verse [6:11](../06/11.md). Alternate translation: [because they have filled the earth with their brutality] or [because all over the earth they are doing harmful things]
This phrase draws extra attention to what God says next. Consider what is the best way to do that in your language. Alternate translation: [Now listen]
Alternate translation: [I plan to destroy them] or [I will destroy them]
This phrase includes everything on the earth, not just the people. Alternate translation: [as well as everything else on the earth]

text: Make for yourself an ark of gopher wood; make rooms in the ark and coat it with pitch inside and out.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Consequently, you must make]

The term ark is a Latin word that many translations use for the name of the structure that Noah built. The word refers to a chest or box that is closed on all sides, including the top. In this case, the ark was a very large boat that people and many animals lived in for a year. It had no motor, no oars, no sail, and no rudder. If Noah’s boat is already well-known as the ark in your language area, you may choose to borrow the word “ark” as the name of this boat. Decide what is best for your translation. Alternate translation: [a very large houseboat]

It is not certain what kind of wood this was, so many translations transliterate (copy or borrow) the Hebrew word **gopher**. Some Bible scholars think it was cypress wood. Alternate translation: [from cypress wood, which is good for building boats]
Alternate translation: [Build the ark with stalls inside] or [Make rooms inside the ark]
Alternate translation: [and completely coat it inside and outside]

The Hebrew word **covering** is general and does not specify what kind of waterproofing material is being used. However, many translations are more specific than that here and refer to “pitch” or “tar” or some other material made from tree resin or sap that can seal a boat well and keep it from leaking. Alternate translation: [with pitch to keep water out] or [with pitch to keep the boat from leaking]

text: And this is how you are to build it: The ark is to be 300 cubits long, 50 cubits wide, and 30 cubits high.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Build the ark with these dimensions] or [You must build the ark like this:]

A cubit was about half a meter (18 inches) long, which was the distance from a man’s elbow to the tip of his middle finger. You can: (1) translate cubits into meters or feet, and put the literal text in a footnote; or (2) keep **cubits** in the main text (so that the numbers 300, 50, and [30](../06/30.md) are kept) and put what that equals in meters or feet in a footnote. Alternate translation: [It must be 140 meters long, 23 meters wide, and 14 meters high] or [It must be 450 feet long, 75 feet wide, and 45 feet high]

text: You are to make a roof for the ark, finish its walls a cubit from the top, place a door in the side of the ark, and build lower, middle, and upper decks.

translation_challenges.note: The meaning of the Hebrew text is not completely certain here, but God was probably telling Noah to make a one-cubit high window or opening at the top of the outside walls of the ark, just below the roof, all the way around the ark, to let light and air into the ark. See the note about **cubit** in verse [6:15](../06/15.md). Alternate translation: [Build a skylight for the boat by finishing the sides of the ark to within one cubit below the top of the ark] or [Build a half-meter high window between the top of the sides of the ark and its roof all the way around, to let light and air in]

Some translations begin this sentence without a conjunction (**And** or “Also”). Do what is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Also put a door in the side of the ark] or [Put a door for the ark in its side]

Alternate translation: [Build a lower deck, a middle deck, and an upper deck on the inside] or [and build a lower, middle, and upper story on the inside] or [and make three complete floors on the inside]

text: And behold, I will bring floodwaters upon the earth to destroy every creature under the heavens that has the breath of life. Everything on the earth will perish.

translation_challenges.note: In the Hebrew text, the pronoun **I** is emphatic, both by its form and by its position at the beginning of the sentence. Consider what is the best way to communicate that emphasis in your language. Alternate translation: [Behold, I myself]
Alternate translation: [am going to send an excessive water on the whole earth] or [am going to flood the entire earth with water]
See how you translated **destroy** in verse [6:13](../06/13.md). Alternate translation: [in order to destroy]

This phrase is general here and includes people and animals, so you may need to translate the phrase differently here from what you did earlier in [verses 12-13](../06/12.md) (where the focus seems to be on people). Alternate translation: [all the beings] or [every creature]
See how you translated this phrase in Genesis [1:30](../01/30.md). Alternate translation: [that breathes air]

For some languages it may be clearer to put this phrase earlier in this sentence and say, “to destroy every living thing under the heavens that has the breath of life in it.” Alternate translation: [from under the sky]
Alternate translation: [So, every living being that lives on land]

The verb **expire** (which could also be translated “exhale” or “breathe out”) is used here as a common expression that means “die.” Consider whether your language has a similar or different expressions that would work well here. Alternate translation: [will breathe out its last breath!] or [will perish!]

text: But I will establish My covenant with you, and you will enter the ark—you and your sons and your wife and your sons’ wives with you.

translation_challenges.note: The word **establish** means to deliberately and formally put something into effect. Alternate translation: [However, I will make] or [However, I will set up]
Alternate translation: [so you must enter the ark]
Alternate translation: [and take with you your wife, your sons, and their wives]

text: And you are to bring two of every living creature into the ark—male and female—to keep them alive with you.

translation_challenges.note: Here, **living creature** refers to any kind of animal that lives and breathes. Alternate translation: [Also, from every kind of thing that lives, yes, from every kind of animal, you must take pairs of each kind into the ark] or [You must also bring into the ark pairs of every kind of living thing, that is, every kind of animal]

These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. Hebrew poetry was based on this kind of repetition, and it would be good to show this to your readers by including both phrases in your translation rather than combining them. It may be clearer in your language to connect the phrases with a word other than **and** in order to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Alternate translation: [Also, from every kind of thing that lives, yes, from every kind of animal]
Alternate translation: [in order to keep them alive with you]
Alternate translation: [They must be pairs with one male and one female each] or [Make sure that each pair has one male and one female]

text: Two of every kind of bird and animal and crawling creature will come to you to be kept alive.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Males and females of every type of bird]
Alternate translation: [and of every kind of animal]
This phrase emphasizes that the birds and animals mentioned in the first half of this verse lived on land. Alternate translation: [including every kind of creature that lives on the land]

For some languages it is more natural to change the order of clauses in this sentence and say, “Two of every kind of bird and every kind of animal, including every kind of creature that moves on the ground, will come to you … ” Alternate translation: [two of every kind of animal will come to you] or [two of each kind of animal will come to you]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these clauses, since the second clause explains the purpose for the action that the previous clause describes. Alternate translation: [to keep them alive on the ark] or [so that you keep them alive in the ark]

text: You are also to take for yourself every kind of food that is eaten and gather it as food for yourselves and for the animals.”

translation_challenges.note: Although the pronoun **you** is singular in the Hebrew text in [verse 21](../06/21.md), it could be translated as plural, since God’s instructions apply to Noah and his family, not just Noah. Or you could make his family explicit. Alternate translation: [You and your family]
Alternate translation: [must also gather and take]
Alternate translation: [all kinds of food]
Alternate translation: [that is eaten by people and animals] or [that you and all the animals will need]
Alternate translation: [and put it on the ark with you]
Alternate translation: [This will be the food supply]
Consider again how you translated the pronoun **you** in this verse.

text: So Noah did everything precisely as God had commanded him.

translation_challenges.note: Some translations begin [verse 22](../06/22.md) without a conjunction. Alternate translation: [Noah did all of that]
Alternate translation: [he did all the things just as God had told him to do]

text: Then the LORD said to Noah, “Go into the ark, you and all your family, because I have found you righteous in this generation.

translation_challenges.note: For some languages it may be necessary to make it explicit that the boat was completed before Yahweh told Noah to enter it. Alternate translation: [Then after they had finished building the ark, Yahweh told Noah] or [After the ark was finished, Yahweh told Noah]
See how you translated “ark” in Genesis [6:14–16](../06/14.md). Alternate translation: [Board the ark along with your entire family] or [You and your entire family must get into the ark]
Alternate translation: [because I have found] or [because I see]

In the Hebrew text, the pronoun **you** is emphasized to show that Noah was the only one who was righteous. See how you translated **righteous** in Genesis [6:9](../06/09.md) Alternate translation: [that you alone are upright] or [that you are the only one who is living the right way]
Alternate translation: [in my eyes] or [according to my will]
For some languages it may be more natural to put this phrase earlier in this verse, after “because.” Alternate translation: [among the people living today]

text: You are to take with you seven pairs of every kind of clean animal, a male and its mate; a pair of every kind of unclean animal, a male and its mate;

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [From every kind of animal that is acceptable to sacrifice]
The pronoun **you** is singular in the Hebrew text, but could be translated as a plural to include Noah’s family. Alternate translation: [bring with you]
See how you translated “male and female” in Genesis [6:19](../06/19.md).
Alternate translation: [and from every kind of impure animal] or [and from every kind of animal that is not acceptable to sacrifice]

text: and seven pairs of every kind of bird of the air, male and female, to preserve their offspring on the face of all the earth.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [from every type of bird that flies in the sky] or [from every type of bird]
See how you translated a similar phrase in [verse 2](../07/02.md). Also, for some languages it may be better to put this phrase earlier in the sentence, as in the UST.
Alternate translation: [so that later they will have offspring that will live]
Alternate translation: [and spread all over the earth] or [to repopulate the whole earth]

text: For seven days from now I will send rain on the earth for forty days and forty nights, and I will wipe from the face of the earth every living thing I have made.”

translation_challenges.note: The word translated as **because** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation: [The reason you must do so is that]

The phrase **seven more days** could be translated as “another week” here and in [verse 11](../07/11.md). However, it is probably best to keep the number seven in the text in both places, especially since the number seven often signifies perfection or completion in the Bible, perhaps also here. Alternate translation: [seven days from now]
Alternate translation: [I will send rain]
Alternate translation: [all over the world]
This phrase refers to 40 complete 24-hour days.
See how you translated this common expression in [6:7](../06/07.md). Alternate translation: [in order to blot out] or [That will wash away]
See how you translated a similar phrase (“living creature”) in Genesis [6:19](../06/19.md). Alternate translation: [all the living things that I have made]

It may be clearer to put this phrase earlier in the sentence and say, “in order to completely destroy from the ground every living creature that I have made.” See how you translated this phrase in Genesis [6:7](../06/07.md). Alternate translation: [off the surface of the earth] or [off the land]

text: And Noah did all that the LORD had commanded him.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [So Noah did everything that] or [So Noah did everything just as]
See how you translated [6:22](../06/22.md), which is similar to [7:5](../07/05.md). Alternate translation: [Yahweh had told him to do]

text: Now Noah was 600 years old when the floodwaters came upon the earth.

translation_challenges.note: See how you handled large numbers in [Genesis 5](../05/01.md) and in Genesis [6:3](../06/03.md), and see the note about this at Genesis [5:35](../05/35.md). Also see how you translated the common expression “son of … years” in Genesis [5:32](../05/32.md). Alternate translation: [He was 600 years old]

For some languages it may be more natural to put this clause first in this sentence and say, “When the flood waters came on the earth, Noah was 600 years old.” Also, see how you translated **floodwaters** in Genesis [6:17](../06/17.md). The phrase **in you** refers to Abram and his descendants, including, ultimately, the Messiah. In other words, God’s promise in this verse is part of his wonderful news (the gospel message) for all people (Galatians [3:8–9](../03/08.md)) and is a prophecy about the Messiah, who was one of Abraham’s descendants (Matthew [1:1](../01/01.md), Genesis [22:18](../22/18.md), and Galatians [3:16](../03/16.md)). God blessed all people on earth by sending his Son Jesus (the Messiah/Christ) to die in their place and pay for all their sins (John [3:16–18](../03/16.md), 1 Timothy [2:3–6](../02/03.md)), so that they could have a close relationship with him/God and be part of his family forever. God repeats this great promise in Genesis [18:18](../18/18.md); [22:18](../22/18.md); [26:4](../26/04.md); [28:14](../28/14.md). You could put some of that information in a footnote.
