Animals that were sacrificed to God as burnt offerings were killed first before they were burned on an altar. Make sure your translation does not sound like the ram was burned alive. If that is not clear, you could make some of the above implied information explicit in your translation. Alternate translation: [Then he killed the ram and burned it on the altar as a offering to God]
Alternate translation: [as a substitute for his son]

translation_challenges.note: Make sure it is clear that what Yahweh did in [verse 13](../22/13.md) is the reason that Abraham gave that place the name **Yahweh-Yireh** in [verse 14](../22/14.md). Alternate translation: [That is why Abraham called that place] or [Because God provided the ram, Abraham called that place]

This refers to the time period when Moses was writing this book. If that is not clear, you could put that information in a footnote. Alternate translation: [Even now people still say]
See how you translated this idiom in [verse 8](../22/08.md). Alternate translation: [it will be provided by him] or [he will see to it that we have what we need] or [he will provide what we need]

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated “called … from heaven” in [verse 11](../22/11.md), and how you translated **angel** in [verses 11-12](../22/11.md).

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **swear** in Genesis [21:23–24](../21/23.md).
Alternate translation: [that since you have done what I said] or [that since you obeyed me]
See how you translated a similar phrase in [verse 12](../22/12.md). Alternate translation: [and did not refuse to sacrifice your son to me] or [were willing to give your son to me]
See how you translated this in [verse 12](../22/12.md). Alternate translation: [even though he is your only son]

text: I will surely bless you, and I will multiply your descendants like the stars in the sky and the sand on the seashore. Your descendants will possess the gates of their enemies.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [I will surely bless you] or [I will surely cause you to prosper greatly]
Alternate translation: [I will greatly increase the number of your descendants so that they will be] or [In fact, I will give you so many offspring that they will be]

Make sure it is clear in your translation that God is comparing the number of stars and grains of sand to the number of descendants Abraham will have. There will be so many that no one can count them all (as in Genesis [13:16](../13/16.md) and [15:6](../15/06.md)). Alternate translation: [as many as the stars in the sky]
Alternate translation: [and as many as the grains of sand on the seashore]

Cities often had high stone walls surrounding them to protect the people inside. The gates in the walls were the only way to go in or out of a city. The idiom “possess the gates of … enemies” refers to taking control of the cities and conquering the people living there. Consider what is the best way to translate this idiom in your language. translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **offspring** in [verse 17](../22/17.md). Alternate translation: [In your offspring] or [Because of your offspring] or [By means of your offspring]

translation_challenges.note: Make sure your translation does not sound like Abraham returned alone (without Isaac). Alternate translation: [Afterwards Abraham and Isaac went back]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then she died] or [before she died]

Alternate translation: [Then Abraham came to her] or [Abraham came to her side]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Later he got up from mourning beside] or [After a while, Abraham left]

King Abimelech uses a rhetorical question here to show strong emotion and to emphasize that what Isaac did was wrong and should not have been done. Alternate translation: [Why did you treat us this way?] or [You should not have done this to us!]

See how you translated the idiom “lay with” in Genesis [19:32–35](../19/32.md). It may be necessary to translate this in slightly different ways, depending on the context. Alternate translation: [Sooner or later, one of the men whom I rule could have slept with your wife] or [… had physical relations with your wife] or [… committed adultery with your wife]

The pronoun **us** in this verse refers to King Abimelech and the Philistines whom he ruled; it does not include Isaac. Alternate translation: [with the result that you would have brought punishment on us!]

text: So Abimelech warned all the people, saying, “Whoever harms this man or his wife will surely be put to death.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then King Abimelech told all his people]

In this context **touches** is used as an idiom that means “harms in any way.” Many languages have a similar idiom that fits well here. Alternate translation: [If anyone harms this man Isaac or his wife in any way, I will surely have that person executed!] or [I will surely execute anyone who harms Isaac or his wife in any way!]

text: Now Isaac sowed seed in the land, and that very year he reaped a hundredfold. And the LORD blessed him,

Alternate translation: [Are you truly my son Esau?]
Alternate translation: [Jacob answered him]
Alternate translation: [Yes, I am Esau] or [Yes, Father I am]

text: “Serve me,” said Isaac, “and let me eat some of my son’s game, so that I may bless you.” Jacob brought it to him, and he ate; then he brought him wine, and he drank.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [So his father said to him]
Your translation of Isaac’s request should sound polite, not rude or demanding. It should also not sound like he was begging or pleading. Alternate translation: [Please bring me the food]
Alternate translation: [So Jacob brought the meal to his father, and he ate it]
See how you translated **wine** in Genesis [19:32–35](../19/32.md). Alternate translation: [Jacob also brought him wine, and he drank it]

text: Then his father Isaac said to him, “Please come near and kiss me, my son.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then Isaac said to him]
See how you translated this phrase in [verse 21](../27/21.md). Alternate translation: [Come near to me]

It was a Hebrew custom for relatives and close friends to greet each other with a kiss on each cheek. Also consider whether it is more natural in your language to put the address **my son** first in this quote.

text: So he came near and kissed him. When Isaac smelled his clothing, he blessed him and said: “Ah, the smell of my son is like the smell of a field that the LORD has blessed.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **went close** in [verse 22](../27/22.md). Alternate translation: [Then Jacob came close to his father]
Alternate translation: [and kissed him on his cheek]
Alternate translation: [by saying to him] or [He said to him]

Some translations put the words of Isaac’s blessing in poetry format (beginning here and through [verse 29](../27/29.md)). Be consistent here with how your translation team decides to format passages like this. Alternate translation: [Ah, my son smells]
Alternate translation: [that Yahweh has caused to be very productive!]
Alternate translation: [Then he blessed him]

text: May God give to you the dew of heaven and the richness of the earth—an abundance of grain and new wine.

translation_challenges.note: In the Hebrew text, **you** is singular in [verses 28-29](../27/28.md) and refers to both Jacob and his descendants. If necessary, you could make that explicit in your translation. Alternate translation: [May God give you and your descendants] or [I pray that God will give you and your descendants]
Alternate translation: [plenty of dew from the heavens for your crops and animals and riches from the soil] or [plenty of rain and rich soil]
Alternate translation: [including an abundance of food and drink] or [so that you have abundant food and much wine]

text: May peoples serve you and nations bow down to you. May you be the master of your brothers, and may the sons of your mother bow down to you. May those who curse you be cursed, and those who bless you be blessed.”

translation_challenges.note: If possible in your language, it is best to keep both halves of this parallelism, which is used to emphasize what Isaac is saying to Jacob. Alternate translation: [May people groups serve you and your descendants, and may they bow down to you in respect]
Alternate translation: [May you rule] or [You will even rule]
Jacob only had one brother, so this phrase refers here to Esau and his descendants. Alternate translation: [over your brother and his descendants]

This clause is another way of referring to Jacob’s authority over Esau and his descendants. Consider again how you translated the singular **you** in [verses 28-29](../27/28.md). You could use a plural **you** here or you could say “you and your descendants.” Alternate translation: [and they will bow down to you in submission] or [Yes, they too will submit to you and bow down to you]

text: As soon as Isaac had finished blessing him and Jacob had left his father’s presence, his brother Esau returned from the hunt.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [came back from hunting]

text: He too made some tasty food, brought it to his father, and said to him, “My father, sit up and eat of your son’s game, so that you may bless me.”

translation_challenges.note: Consider again how you translated **prepared tasty food** in [verses 4](../27/04.md), [7](../27/07.md), [9](../27/09.md), [14](../27/14.md), [31](../27/31.md) and **tasty** in [verse 17](../27/17.md). Alternate translation: [Then Esau also cooked a tasty meal with the meat he had hunted]
Alternate translation: [and he carried it to his father Isaac]
Alternate translation: [and requested]

text: But his father Isaac replied, “Who are you?” “I am Esau, your firstborn son,” he answered.

translation_challenges.note: For some languages it is more natural to make **Isaac** explicit in [verse 31](../27/31.md) and leave it implied here in [verse 32](../27/32.md). Alternate translation: [Then his father asked him] or [But his father exclaimed]

Isaac knew from what Esau just said in [verse 31](../27/31.md) that one of his sons was talking to him. Also, Isaac is very upset, so some translations add an exclamation point after the question mark to help communicate that. Alternate translation: [Which of my sons are you?!]
Alternate translation: [Esau answered him] or [Esau replied]
See how you translated **firstborn** in [verse 19](../27/19.md). Alternate translation: [I am your firstborn son Esau] or [I am Esau, your oldest son]

text: Isaac began to tremble violently and said, “Who was it, then, who hunted the game and brought it to me? Before you came in, I ate it all and blessed him—and indeed, he will be blessed!”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then Isaac became so upset that he shook very violently] or [Then Isaac was very upset, so that he began to shake all over]
Alternate translation: [Then where is the one]

Consider again how you translated **game** in Genesis [27:3](../27/03.md), [5](../27/05.md), [7](../27/07.md), [19](../27/19.md), [25](../27/25.md), [31](../27/31.md) and [33](../27/33.md). It may be necessary to translate it in slightly different ways, depending on the context. Alternate translation: [who hunted game meat and brought a meal to me?] or [who brought to me a meal made from wild animal meat?]
Alternate translation: [Just before you came to me, I finished eating the meal] or [I finished eating it just before you came here]

The expression **he will be blessed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [and then I blessed him. And God will surely bless him] or [Then I asked God to bless him, so God will definitely bless him]

text: When Esau heard his father’s words, he let out a loud and bitter cry and said to his father, “Bless me too, O my father!”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [When Esau heard what his father said to him]
Alternate translation: [he burst out with an extremely loud and bitter cry] or [he was so upset that he yelled out loudly]
Alternate translation: [and begged him]
For some languages it is more natural to put the address “My father” or “Father” first in this sentence. Alternate translation: [Father, please bless me too!]

text: But Isaac replied, “Your brother came deceitfully and took your blessing.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [But his father replied to him]
Alternate translation: [Your brother came to me and deceived me and stole the blessing that I was planning to give you] or [Your brother deceived me so that I blessed him instead of you!]

text: So Esau declared, “Is he not rightly named Jacob? For he has cheated me twice. He took my birthright, and now he has taken my blessing.” Then he asked, “Haven’t you saved a blessing for me?”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then Esau exclaimed angrily] or [When Esau heard that, he said angrily]

Esau uses a rhetorical question here to show his strong emotion. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. To help readers understand why Esau said this about Jacob, you could include a footnote such as the following: The name **Jacob** means “heel-grabber” and can imply deception. He was given that name because when he was born he was grabbing hold of Esau’s heel (Genesis [25:26](../25/26.md)). Alternate translation: [It is no wonder that he is called Jacob, since he has cheated me two times!]
Alternate translation: [First he stole my rights as the oldest son, and now see what he has done:] or [Not only did he take my birthright, but now see what he has done:]
Alternate translation: [he has also stolen my blessing!] or [he has tricked you into blessing him instead of me!]
Alternate translation: [Then he begged his father] or [Then he pleaded with his father]

text: But Isaac answered Esau: “Look, I have made him your master and given him all his relatives as servants; I have sustained him with grain and new wine. What is left that I can do for you, my son?”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Isaac replied to Esau] or [Isaac answered him]

See how you translated **brothers** in [verse 29](../27/29.md). Alternate translation: [In fact, I said that you and all your descendants will serve him] or [In fact, I have asked God to make it so that you and your descendants will serve him and his descendants]

See how you translated **grain and wine** in [verse 28](../27/28.md). Alternate translation: [Besides that, I have also supplied him with abundant food and wine] or [I have also asked God to supply him with plenty of food and wine]
Isaac uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that there is no blessing left for Esau. Alternate translation: [So, my son, there is no blessing left for you!]

text: Esau said to his father, “Do you have only one blessing, my father? Bless me too, O my father!” Then Esau wept aloud.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [But Esau continued to beg his father and said] or [But again Esau begged]
It may be more natural to put **my father** or “Father” first in this quote. See what you did in [verse 34](../27/34.md).
See how you translated this sentence in [verse 34](../27/34.md). Alternate translation: [Father, please bless me too!]
See how you translated “lifted … voice and sobbed” in Genesis [21:16](../21/16.md). Alternate translation: [Then Esau started sobbing loudly]

text: His father Isaac answered him: “Behold, your dwelling place shall be away from the richness of the land, away from the dew of heaven above.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [So his father Isaac said to him] or [His father replied]
What Isaac says in [verses 39-40](../27/39.md) applies to Esau and his descendants. See what you did for a similar case in [verses 28-29](../27/28.md).

This could mean: (1) “in a place where the ground is not fertile and where there is very little rain.” Alternate translation: [in a place where the land is not good for farming and where there is not much rain] or (2) “of the fatness of the earth and of the dew of the heavens from above.” Alternate translation: [in a place where the land is good for farming and where there is plenty of rain] See how you translated **fatness of the earth** and **dew of the heavens** in [verse 28](../27/28.md).

text: You shall live by the sword and serve your brother. But when you rebel, you will tear his yoke from your neck.”

translation_challenges.note: The phrase **live by your sword** is an idiom that means Esau and his descendants will have violent conflict with others, often in order to survive. Alternate translation: [You and your descendants will survive by using your swords to protect yourselves] or [You and your descendants will continually be fighting battles with other peoples]
Alternate translation: [and you and your descendants will serve your brother and his descendants] or [and you and your descendants will be servants for your brother and his descendants]

Consider again how you translated the singular **you** in [verses 39-40](../27/39.md). You could use a plural **you** here or you could say “you and your descendants.” See what you did for a similar case in [verses 28-29](../27/28.md). Alternate translation: [But when you revolt against him]

The verbal image **break his yoke off of your neck** means that Esau and his descendants will be free from the control of Jacob and his descendants. A yoke is a wooden collar that is placed around the necks of work animals to control them as they pull a plow or cart. Alternate translation: [you will get free from his rule over you] or [you will no longer be under his rule]

text: Esau held a grudge against Jacob because of the blessing his father had given him. And Esau said in his heart, “The days of mourning for my father are at hand; then I will kill my brother Jacob.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [After that, Esau held a grudge against Jacob] or [Esau continued to be very angry at Jacob]

The author is repeating forms of the verb **blessed** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [because his father had given his blessing to Jacob] or [because their father had blessed Jacob instead of him]
Alternate translation: [So Esau said to himself]
Alternate translation: [I am going to kill] or [I plan to kill]

In that culture, they had the custom of mourning the death of a loved one for a certain period of time, anywhere from a week to a month or more. See how you translated “mourn” in [Gen 23:2](../23/02.md). Alternate translation: [Soon my father will die, and we will have a time of mourning for him, then]

text: When the words of her older son Esau were relayed to Rebekah, she sent for her younger son Jacob and told him, “Look, your brother Esau is consoling himself by plotting to kill you.

translation_challenges.note: It was probably a servant who told Rebekah about Esau’s plan to kill Jacob. Alternate translation: [Then someone told Rebekah what Esau was saying so] or [Then Rebekah heard about what her older son Esau was planning, so] or [When Rebekah heard what Esau was planning to do]
Alternate translation: [she sent for her younger son Jacob to come to her] or [she sent a messenger to tell Jacob to come to her] or [she summoned her son Jacob]
Alternate translation: [and warned him]
Alternate translation: [Look your brother Esau is making himself feel better by planning to kill you]

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **So now** in [verses 3](../27/03.md) and [8](../27/08.md). Alternate translation: [Now son]

See how you translated this phrase in [verses 8](../27/08.md) and [13](../27/13.md). It may be necessary to translate it differently here because of the context. Alternate translation: [do what I tell you:]
Alternate translation: [get ready immediately and flee] or [Hurry and flee] or [Flee immediately]

For some languages, it is more natural to put the location (Haran) before the person who lives there (Laban). Alternate translation: [to my brother Laban who lives in the city of Haran!] or [to the city of Haran, to the house of my brother Laban!]

text: Stay with him for a while, until your brother’s fury subsides—

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Stay with him for a short time]

Consider whether it is more natural in your language to end this sentence here or to continue the sentence into [verse 45](../27/45.md). Also, the phrase **turns away** is used here as an idiom that means “becomes less” or “goes away.” Alternate translation: [until your brother is no longer furious with you]

text: until your brother’s rage against you wanes and he forgets what you have done to him. Then I will send for you and bring you back from there. Why should I lose both of you in one day?”

translation_challenges.note: Notice that the Hebrew word for **anger** here is different from the stronger word (“fury”) in [verse 44](../27/44.md). Alternate translation: [until his anger against you is gone] or [After a while, when your brother is no longer angry with you]

Rebekah is not saying that Esau would totally forget what Jacob did, but that at some point he would not hold it against him anymore. Alternate translation: [and he no longer thinks about what you did]
Alternate translation: [I will send someone to tell you when it is safe to come back home]

Rebekah knew that if Esau were to kill Jacob, he himself would have been killed for that crime. Consider whether it is best in your language to use a rhetorical question or an exclamation to emphasize Rebekah’s concern. Alternate translation: [I do not want both my sons to be killed!]

text: Then Rebekah said to Isaac, “I am weary of my life because of these Hittite women. If Jacob takes a Hittite wife from among them, what good is my life?”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Soon after that, Rebekah said to Isaac]
Rebekah is exaggerating how she feels to influence Isaac to do what she wants. Alternate translation: [I do not enjoy living] or [I am very upset]

To show that Rebekah is speaking with strong emotion, you could use an exclamation point at the end of this sentence and the following one. Alternate translation: [because of the Hittite women whom Esau married!]
Alternate translation: [If Jacob also marries a Hittite woman from around here]
Rebekah uses a rhetorical question and an extreme statement to emphasize how upset she would be if Jacob married a Hittite woman. Alternate translation: [my life will not be worth living!]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [So Isaac sent for Jacob to come to him] or [Because of what Rebekah said, Isaac summoned Jacob]
For some languages it may be necessary to make it explicit that Jacob arrived. Alternate translation: [Then he blessed him] or [After he came, Isaac blessed him]
Alternate translation: [and instructed him]

If the word “woman” is used here in your translation, make sure it refers to a virgin woman who has never been married, or is general enough to include that. Alternate translation: [and find a woman from there to marry]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [and enable you to have many children]

Alternate translation: [so that you become the ancestor of many ethnic groups] or [so that many people groups will descend from you] or [so that they become many ethnic groups]

Alternate translation: [that the female sheep and goats were in heat] or [that the flocks of sheep and goats were mating]

text: In that dream the angel of God said to me, ‘Jacob!’ And I replied, ‘Here I am.’

Alternate translation: [and observe that]

Alternate translation: [I, Yahweh, have caused that to happen, because I have observed]
Alternate translation: [all the wrong things that Laban has done to you] or [all the ways that Laban has been treating you badly]

See how you translated **vowed a vow** in Genesis [28:20](../28/20.md). Alternate translation: [and where you made a vow to me]

text: And Rachel and Leah replied, “Do we have any portion or inheritance left in our father’s house?

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then Rachel and Leah responded to him] or [Rachel and Leah replied to him]

This rhetorical question expects the answer “no.” It also expresses Rachel’s and Leah’s strong emotion and emphasizes that there is nothing for them to inherit from their father. Consider whether or not a rhetorical question fits well here in your language. Alternate translation: [We no longer have any part in the inheritance from our father.] or [We will never inherit anything from our father!]

text: Are we not regarded by him as outsiders? Not only has he sold us, but he has certainly squandered what was paid for us.

translation_challenges.note: This rhetorical question expects the answer “yes” and expresses Rachel’s and Leah’s anger at how their father treats them. Consider whether or not it is natural in your language to use a rhetorical question here. Alternate translation: [It is obvious that he regards us] or [He obviously is treating us]

Make sure that the punctuation you use here fits with how you translate this rhetorical question. Alternate translation: [like outsiders and not family] or [as if we were foreigners instead of family]
This sentence is an example of how Laban treated his daughters like foreigners. Alternate translation: [After all, he sold us to you]

The phrase **eaten up** is used here as an idiom that means Laban had spent or kept for himself all the wealth he had gained from Jacob’s 14 years of working for him. Many languages have a similar idiom that could be used here. Alternate translation: [and then he used up all]
In that culture at that time, **silver** was a currency used to buy and sell things. Alternate translation: [the wealth that should have been ours] or [the money that belonged to us]

text: Surely all the wealth that God has taken away from our father belongs to us and to our children. So do whatever God has told you.”

text: and he drove all his livestock before him, along with all the possessions he had acquired in Paddan-aram, to go to his father Isaac in the land in Canaan.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then he led] or [Then he started driving]

The word **livestock** is general here and includes all of Jacob’s animals. Alternate translation: [the camels and all his other livestock and along with them, he also took all the other possessions that he had acquired]

He took with him all his possessions that he had accumulated, including all the livestock that he had acquired/accumulated while living in the land/region of Paddan Aram.” Alternate translation: [to go to Canaan, to the home of his father Isaac] or [to the land of Canaan, where his father Isaac lived]

text: Now while Laban was out shearing his sheep, Rachel stole her father’s household idols.

translation_challenges.note: Make sure it is clear in your translation that the events in [verse 19](../31/19.md) happened before Jacob and his family had left. Also, for some languages it is more natural to first make “the Aramean” explicit here in [verse 19](../31/19.md) rather than wait until [verse 20](../31/20.md).

In that culture, sheep wool was very important since it was used to make clothing and blankets. The process of shearing many sheep would have taken several days. You could include some of this information in a footnote. Alternate translation: [had gone away for several days to cut the wool off his sheep]
Alternate translation: [While he was gone, Rachel entered his tent and took]

The author assumes that readers will know that these **idols** were statues made of wood or precious metals and were small enough to be used in a private home. You could say that explicitly if that would be helpful to your readers. In this chapter these statues are referred to as **idols** (in [verses 19](../31/19.md), [34](../31/34.md), [35](../31/35.md) when the author refers to them) and “gods” (in quotes in [verses 30](../31/30.md) and [32](../31/32.md) when Laban or Jacob talk about them). If it is confusing in your language to switch back and forth between these two terms, you could use “gods” throughout this chapter, since Laban would not have called them idols, and Jacob would not have used that term in his presence. However, if possible, it is best to translate the two terms the way the Hebrew text has them. Alternate translation: [his family gods] or [the gods that he had]

text: Moreover, Jacob deceived Laban the Aramean by not telling him that he was running away.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [and Jacob tricked] or [At the same time, Jacob tricked]

Alternate translation: [and went in the direction of]

The Hebrew text is ambiguous here. It could refer to: (1) mountains or hill country; or (2) a specific mountain (“Mount Gilead”). Alternate translation: [the mountain region called Gilead] or [the hill country called Gilead]

Alternate translation: [but he did not find his gods]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then the man said to Jacob]

The wording here is similar to what God said when he changed Abram’s name to Abraham (Genesis [17:5](../17/05.md)) and Sarai’s name to Sarah ([17:15](../17/15.md)). After that, Abraham and Sarah were no longer called by their previous names. In the case of Jacob, he continues to be referred to by both of his names in this chapter (**Jacob** in [verses 29-30](../32/29.md), [32](../32/32.md); **Israel** in [verse 32](../32/32.md)) and throughout the rest of the Bible, including by God (Genesis [46:2](../46/02.md)). It could be that although God was changing Jacob’s primary name to “Israel,” he was still known by his previous name too. You could put some of that information in a footnote. Alternate translation: [You will no longer be named Jacob]
If you include the meaning of the name **Israel** in your translation or in a footnote, make sure it fits with how you translate **struggled** in the following clause.

The Hebrew word for **struggled** here is more general than the word for “wrestled” in [verses 24](../32/24.md) and [25](../32/25.md). Alternate translation: [because you have struggled against both God and men]

See how you translated **prevailed** in [verse 25](../32/25.md) and Genesis [30:8](../30/08.md). It may be necessary to translate this term in slightly different ways, depending on the context. Alternate translation: [and you have overcome]

text: And Jacob requested, “Please tell me your name.” But he replied, “Why do you ask my name?” Then he blessed Jacob there.

translation_challenges.note: Consider again whether or not you have capitalized references to the man in [verses 24-29](../32/24.md). See the note about this at [verse 24](../32/24.md). Alternate translation: [Then Jacob asked him]
Consider whether it is better to use a direct or indirect quote here in your language. Alternate translation: [What is your name?] or [what his name was]
Alternate translation: [But the man replied]

This rhetorical question probably means that there was no need for Jacob to ask the man what his name was; he should have known without asking. Consider whether or not it is best to use a rhetorical question here in your language. Alternate translation: [You do not need to ask me]
Alternate translation: [to tell you my name!]

text: So Jacob named the place Peniel, saying, “Indeed, I have seen God face to face, and yet my life was spared.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [I saw God in person here]

The author assumes that readers will know that Jacob was amazed that he was still alive because, although there were exceptions ([Exodus 33:11](../../exo/33/11.md); [Judges 13:22](../../jdg/13/22.md)), normally people could not see God face to face and live ([Exodus 33:20](../../exo/33/20.md)). You could put that information in a footnote so that readers understand why Jacob was surprised. Alternate translation: [but yet my life was spared by him!]

text: The sun rose above him as he passed by Penuel, and he was limping because of his hip.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [The sun shined on Jacob] or [The sun was rising]

Penuel is another name for the place that is called Peniel in [verse 30](../32/30.md). That information could be put in a footnote. Or you could use the same spelling in both verses to avoid confusion; **Penuel** is the spelling in the rest of the Old Testament. Alternate translation: [as he left Penuel and returned to his family]
Alternate translation: [As he walked, he was limping]
Alternate translation: [because his hip joint was injured]

text: Therefore to this day the Israelites do not eat the tendon attached to the socket of the hip, because the socket of Jacob’s hip was struck near that tendon.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [even now] or [even in the present]
Alternate translation: [the descendants of Israel] or [the Israelites]
Alternate translation: [do not eat the tendon]
Make sure it is clear in your translation that this is talking about eating meat from an animal, not about cannibalism.
See how you translated the idiom **touched** in [verse 25](../32/25.md).

text: Now Jacob looked up and saw Esau coming toward him with four hundred men. So he divided the children among Leah, Rachel, and the two maidservants.

translation_challenges.note: Make sure your translation of this idiom does not mean that Jacob looked straight up. Rather, he probably looked carefully to the south (the direction that his brother was coming from). Alternate translation: [Then Jacob looked up and saw] or [Then Jacob looked ahead of him and saw]
Esau was still a fair distance away, which gave Jacob time to do everything that he does in [verses 1-3](../33/01.md). Alternate translation: [that Esau was in the distance coming his way]
Alternate translation: [with 400 men!] or [and that he had 400 men with him!]

Each of the women had her own children with her ([verse 2](../33/02.md)). See how you translated **divided** in Genesis [32:7](../32/07.md) and “his two maidservants” in Genesis [32:22](../32/22.md). Alternate translation: [So he quickly put his children into groups with their own mothers, Leah, Rachel and his two servant wives] or [So he had his children quickly gather with their own mothers, so that Leah, Rachel and his two concubines were each with her own children]

text: He put the maidservants and their children in front, Leah and her children next, and Rachel and Joseph at the rear.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated “his two maidservants” in Genesis [32:22](../32/22.md). Alternate translation: [He put his two servant wives with their children] or [He put the group that had his two servant wives and their children]

For some languages it is more natural to put phrases like **first** and **after them** at the beginning of their clauses and say, “First in line he put his two servant wives and/with their children. Behind them he put Leah and/with her children, and last of all he put Rachel and/with her son Joseph.” Alternate translation: [in front of all the others]
Alternate translation: [then he put Leah and her children]
Alternate translation: [next]
Alternate translation: [and he put Rachel and her son Joseph]
Alternate translation: [behind them all] or [in the rear]

text: But Jacob himself went on ahead and bowed to the ground seven times as he approached his brother.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then Jacob himself walked ahead of them all toward his brother] or [Then he started going toward his brother ahead of them all]

See how you translated “bow down” in Genesis [27:29](../27/29.md). Alternate translation: [and he bowed with his face to the ground seven times to show respect as he went closer to him] or [As he approached Esau, he prostrated himself with his face to the ground seven times to show respect]

text: Esau, however, ran to him and embraced him, threw his arms around his neck, and kissed him. And they both wept.

translation_challenges.note: This sentence shows a contrast between what Jacob was expecting and what actually happened.

See how you translated “hugged him … and kissed him on the cheek/cheeks” in Genesis [29:13](../29/13.md). Make sure that the way you translate **fell on his neck** does not imply that Esau accidentally fell. Rather, this is an idiom that means he embraced Jacob warmly, with much emotion. Alternate translation: [and he threw his arms around his shoulders and kissed him] or [He held Jacob tightly and kissed him on the cheek]

Also, some languages have a dual pronoun for **they** that could be used here. Alternate translation: [and they both cried for joy] or [Both of them cried because they were so happy to see each other again]

text: When Esau looked up and saw the women and children, he asked, “Who are these with you?” Jacob answered, “These are the children God has graciously given your servant.”

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated the idiom “lifted … eyes” in [verse 1](../33/01.md) and Genesis [31:10](../31/10.md). It may be necessary to translate this idiom in different ways, depending on the context. Alternate translation: [Then Esau looked up]
Alternate translation: [and saw the women and children who were there with Jacob]
Alternate translation: [so he asked him]
Esau wants to know if these people are Jacob’s family members or his servants or someone else; he is not asking what their names are. Alternate translation: [How are these people related to you?]
Make sure it is clear in your translation who is speaking to whom here. Alternate translation: [He answered him]
Alternate translation: [They are the children and the wives] or [They are my wives and my children]

Jacob uses the phrase **your servant** to be polite and show respect to Esau; he was not actually Esau’s servant. For some languages it is more natural to put the honorific title first in this sentence and say, “Sir, they are the wives and children whom God has graciously given to me.” Alternate translation: [whom God has kindly given to me, your servant] or [whom God has graciously given to me, sir]

text: Then the maidservants and their children approached and bowed down.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **maidservants** in [verses 1-2](../33/01.md). Alternate translation: [Then the two maidservants came closer to Esau along with their children]
See how you translated **bowed down** in [verse 3](../33/03.md). Alternate translation: [and they all bowed to the ground in front of him to show respect]

text: Leah and her children also approached and bowed down, and then Joseph and Rachel approached and bowed down.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then Leah also came closer to Esau along with her children] or [Next Leah and her children also came closer]
Alternate translation: [Then last of all, Joseph and his mother Rachel came closer]
Some languages have a dual pronoun for **they** that fits here well. See what you did in [verse 4](../33/04.md).

text: “What do you mean by sending this whole company to meet me?” asked Esau. “To find favor in your sight, my lord,” Jacob answered.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then Esau said to Jacob]
Alternate translation: [What do you mean by] or [What is the purpose of]
Alternate translation: [all those groups of livestock]
Alternate translation: [that I saw on my way here?] or [that came to me on my way here?]
Alternate translation: [Jacob said to him]

See how you translated **my lord** and the idiom “find favor in … eyes” in Genesis [32:5](../32/05.md). Alternate translation: [I sent them so that you would be gracious to me, sir] or [They are gifts for you so that you would be pleased with me, sir]

text: “I already have plenty, my brother,” Esau replied. “Keep what belongs to you.”

translation_challenges.note: What Esau says is in contrast to what Jacob said, but it may not be necessary to use a conjunction here at all. Alternate translation: [Esau said to him]

For some languages it is more natural to put the address **my brother** first in this quote. Some languages also have a special term for “younger brother” that fits well here. Alternate translation: [My brother, I already own enough livestock]
Alternate translation: [Keep what you own for yourself] or [so keep your livestock for yourself]

text: But Jacob insisted, “No, please! If I have found favor in your sight, then receive this gift from my hand. For indeed, I have seen your face, and it is like seeing the face of God, since you have received me favorably.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [But Jacob responded to him]

In [verses 10](../33/10.md) and [11](../33/11.md), Jacob speaks urgently to Esau, because in that culture if Esau accepts Jacob’s gift, he is committing himself to treat Jacob as a friend. Alternate translation: [No, I beg you]
Alternate translation: [please accept from me what I have given you]
Alternate translation: [The fact is]

In Old Testament times it was terrifying for someone to see God in person, because normally people could not see God’s face and live ([Exodus 33:20](../../exo/33/20.md)). However, God had been gracious to Jacob and allowed him to live (Genesis [32:30](../32/30.md)). In the same way, it was a terrifying thing for Jacob to see Esau who had 400 men with him, but Esau was gracious to him ([33:4](../33/04.md)). See how you translated a different Hebrew word that means “receive” or “welcome” in Genesis [32:20](../32/20.md). Alternate translation: [I thought you were still angry at me, so I was afraid of seeing you again in person, just as I would be afraid of meeting God in person, but you forgave me and welcomed me!]

text: Please accept my gift that was brought to you, because God has been gracious to me and I have all I need.” So Jacob pressed him until he accepted.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [So please accept my gift of livestock that my servants brought to you] or [So please accept the livestock from me that I sent to you]
Alternate translation: [because God has been generous to me] or [because God has blessed me]
Alternate translation: [and he has given me everything that I need] or [so that I own all that I need]

Make sure it is clear in your translation who and what is being referred to at every point in this sentence. Alternate translation: [He kept urging him to accept his gift] or [He kept insisting that he accept the livestock from him]
Alternate translation: [until finally Esau accepted it]

text: Then Esau said, “Let us be on our way, and I will go ahead of you.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then Esau said to Jacob]
Esau is suggesting that he would accompany or escort Jacob and his family, not that he would go far ahead of them. Alternate translation: [and I will lead you]

text: But Jacob replied, “My lord knows that the children are frail, and I must care for sheep and cattle that are nursing their young. If they are driven hard for even a day, all the animals will die.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [But he replied to him]
See how you translated “my lord” in [verse 8](../33/08.md). Alternate translation: [Sir, you know that]
Alternate translation: [my children are weak]
See how you translated “flocks and herds” in Genesis [12:16](../12/16.md). Alternate translation: [and some of my sheep and cattle are nursing their young]
Alternate translation: [If my men drive the livestock too hard in one day] or [If I force the livestock to go too fast for even one day]

This phrase especially refers to the sheep and cattle that were nursing, but Jacob is probably using exaggeration here (**all**) to emphasize that he does not want to travel too fast. Alternate translation: [then all the flocks and herds will die] or [then all of them will die]

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated Jacob’s use of **my lord** (in [verse 8](../33/08.md)) and **servant** (in [verse 5](../33/05.md)) to show respect and deference to Esau. Here he uses both terms for emphasis.
Alternate translation: [Then I will travel along slowly at a speed that is good for the livestock and children that are with me]
Alternate translation: [until we reach you, sir] or [We will catch up to you later, sir]

See how you translated “the land of Seir” in Genesis [32:3](../32/03.md). The land of Seir was a mountainous region southeast of the land of Canaan (and the Dead Sea) and was where Esau had settled. It was also called “Edom” (Genesis [32:3](../32/03.md)), which was Esau’s nickname (Genesis [25:30](../25/30.md)). You could put some of that information in a footnote. Alternate translation: [in the land of Seir]

text: “Let me leave some of my people with you,” Esau said. But Jacob replied, “Why do that? Let me find favor in the sight of my lord.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then Esau said to Jacob]
Alternate translation: [Okay, then please let me leave you some of my men to escort you] or [Okay, then may I leave some of my men with you to escort you?]
Make sure the way you translate this quote margin fits with how you translate the previous and following sentences. Alternate translation: [Jacob said to him] or [Jacob answered him]
Jacob uses a rhetorical question here to emphasize that there is no need for Esau to leave any of his men with him. For some languages it is clearer and more natural to use a statement here instead.

Consider again how you translated **my lord** in [verses 8](../33/08.md),[13-15](../33/13.md). For some languages it is more natural to put this address earlier in this quote. Also see how you translated the idiom **find favor in the eyes of** in [verse 8](../33/08.md). Alternate translation: [Just please continue to be gracious to me, sir] or [Sir, please just continue to treat me kindly]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [So that very day Esau and his men started on their way back] or [So that very day Esau and his men left and headed back]

Alternate translation: [There he and his servants built a house for himself and his family] or [where he and his men built a house for his family]

The phrase “he/they called” could refer to Jacob, or it could refer to people in general (as it often does in Genesis). If you include the meaning of the name Succoth in your translation or in a footnote, make sure it matches the way you translate **shelters** earlier in this verse.

text: After Jacob had come from Paddan-aram, he arrived safely at the city of Shechem in the land of Canaan, and he camped just outside the city.

translation_challenges.note: Jacob and his family had left Paddan Aram and had been traveling back to the land of his ancestors in Canaan (Genesis [31:3](../31/03.md), [13](../31/13.md), [18](../31/18.md)). See how you translated **in peace** in Genesis [28:21](../28/21.md). Alternate translation: [Later Jacob and his family arrived safely at the city of Shechem in the land of Canaan, as he continued traveling home from the region of Paddan Aram] or [After that, Jacob and his family continued their journey home from the region of Paddan Aram, until eventually they arrived safely at the city of Shechem in the land of Canaan]
See how you translated **camped** in Genesis [26:17](../26/17.md). Alternate translation: [and he set up camp in a field] or [Then he set up his tents in a field]
Alternate translation: [near the city] or [on the edge of the city]

text: And the plot of ground where he pitched his tent, he purchased from the sons of Hamor, Shechem’s father, for a hundred pieces of silver.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then he bought the plot of land]
Alternate translation: [where they had set up their camp] or [where he were camping]

The weight and value of **a hundred kesitahs** of silver is not known. Some ancient translations (including the LXX and Latin Vulgate) have “a hundred lambs” here, but most modern translations have “a hundred pieces of silver.” Alternate translation: [for one hundred pieces of money from the sons of Hamor who was the father of Shechem]

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **altar** in Genesis [26:25](../26/25.md). Alternate translation: [On that land Jacob also built a stone altar] or [Jacob also made an altar out of stones on that land]

Alternate translation: [Now one day Dinah, who was the daughter whom Leah had for Jacob, went out] or [One day, Dinah, who was the daughter of Jacob and Leah, went to the city]

text: When Shechem son of Hamor the Hivite, the prince of the region, saw her, he took her and lay with her by force.

translation_challenges.note: Consider which order of phrases is best here in your language. Also see how you translated “Hivites” in Genesis [10:17](../10/17.md) and **ruler** in Genesis [25:16](../25/16.md). Alternate translation: [Then Shechem, who was the son of the Hivite named Hamor who ruled that region, saw] or [Now the ruler of that region was a Hivite named Hamor. His son Shechem saw]
Alternate translation: [Dinah, and he grabbed hold of her] or [how beautiful Dinah was, so he took hold of her]

This is a euphemistic way of saying that Shechem forced Dinah to have sex with him. Translate this in a way that will not offend or embarrass people, especially when hearing your translation read aloud. Alternate translation: [and forced her to go to bed with him]

text: And his soul was drawn to Dinah, the daughter of Jacob. He loved the young girl and spoke to her tenderly.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **young woman** in Genesis [24:14](../24/14.md), and see the note about that there. Alternate translation: [and spoke tenderly to her to try to persuade her] or [and tried to win her heart by speaking kindly to her]

text: So Shechem told his father Hamor, “Get me this girl as a wife.”

At that time it was normal for parents to negotiate with another family to get a spouse for their child. The negotiations would include a bride-price and other details. The term **girl** that Shechem uses here is less respectful than the term “young woman” that is used in [verses 3](../34/03.md) and [12](../34/12.md).

Alternate translation: [Shechem had disgraced his daughter Dinah] or [his daughter Dinah had been disgraced by Shechem]
Alternate translation: [his sons were still tending his livestock out in the fields] or [his sons were still out in the fields taking care of his livestock]

Alternate translation: [When they heard that Shechem had raped their sister]

See how you translated **grieved** in Genesis [6:6](../06/06.md). It may be necessary to translate this term in different ways, depending on the context. Alternate translation: [they were very shocked]
See how you translated the idiom “it/anger burned within …” in Genesis [32:36](../32/36.md). Alternate translation: [and filled with anger]

Notice in this verse that the Hebrew text has both of Jacob’s names, **Jacob** and “Israel,” to emphasize that Shechem had sinned against Jacob and all of his descendants (the people of Israel). You could put that information in a footnote. Make sure that your translation of **Israel** does not refer here to a place, since Israel was not yet a country or a territory. Alternate translation: [that Shechem had disgraced the family of Israel]
Alternate translation: [Such a wicked thing should never be done by anyone!] or [No one should ever do such a wicked crime!]

text: But Hamor said to them, “My son Shechem longs for your daughter. Please give her to him as his wife.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [But Hamor pleaded with Jacob and his sons and said] or [But Hamor begged Jacob and his sons]

The pronoun **your** is plural here, which shows that Hamor is addressing not only Jacob but also his sons. Alternate translation: [My son Shechem has fallen completely in love with your daughter and sister]

The way **give** and “take” are used in [verses 8](../34/08.md), [9](../34/09.md), [12](../34/12.md), [16](../34/16.md) and [21](../34/21.md) reflects the culture at that time, when parents or families arranged marriages for their daughters. Also see the note about this at [verse 4](../34/04.md). Alternate translation: [So please permit him to marry her]

You can also do business buying and selling things wherever you want]

Alternate translation: [because that would humiliate our family!] or [That would cause great shame to our family!]

Alternate translation: [You and your people must first become like us]

text: Then we will give you our daughters and take your daughters for ourselves. We will dwell among you and become one people.

Alternate translation: [Then we will let our daughters marry your young men, and our young men will marry your daughters] or [After you do that, then we will allow your young men to marry our daughters, and we will allow your daughters to marry our young men]

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated the idiom “good in … eyes” in Genesis [19:8](../19/08.md). It may need to be translated in different ways, depending on the context.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [So Shechem immediately started] or [So right away Shechem took action]
Alternate translation: [to do what they proposed] or [to do their requirement]

Alternate translation: [and they spoke to the city elders who had gathered there. They said] or [and they told the leaders of their city about Jacob and his sons]

Alternate translation: [Look, there is enough land to support them and us] or [After all, there is more than enough room in this land for them too]

Alternate translation: [So we should just do what they propose]
See how you translated **settle with us** in [verses 10](../34/10.md) and [22](../34/22.md). Alternate translation: [so that they will settle among us!]

text: All the men who went out of the city gate listened to Hamor and his son Shechem, and every male of the city was circumcised.

translation_challenges.note: Make sure that your translation of this idiom refers here to the same men who had gathered at the city gates in [verse 20](../34/20.md). Alternate translation: [All the men who were elders of the city] or [All the men who were there at the city gate]
Alternate translation: [agreed to do what Hamor and his son Shechem said]
Alternate translation: [so all of them and all the other males in the city were circumcised]

text: Three days later, while they were still in pain, two of Jacob’s sons (Dinah’s brothers Simeon and Levi) took their swords, went into the unsuspecting city, and slaughtered every male.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [On the third day after that]
Alternate translation: [when it was still painful for the men of the city to move]
These brothers had the same father and mother as Dinah. Some languages have a special term for this.
See how you translated **sword** in Genesis [27:40](../27/40.md). Alternate translation: [their swords and attacked the city, with no one resisting them]

text: They killed Hamor and his son Shechem with their swords, took Dinah out of Shechem’s house, and went away.

translation_challenges.note: Some languages have dual pronouns for **they** and “you” that can be used in [verses 25-26](../34/25.md) and [30-31](../34/30.md) to refer to Simeon and Levi.
Alternate translation: [and returned home]

text: Jacob’s other sons came upon the slaughter and looted the city, because their sister had been defiled.

translation_challenges.note: All of Jacob’s sons probably joined Simeon and Levi in plundering the city, after those two had killed all the men there ([verse 25](../34/25.md)).

See how you translated **defiled** in [verses 5](../34/05.md) and [13](../34/13.md). Even though Shechem was the one who actually defiled Dinah ([verses 2](../34/02.md), [5](../34/05.md), [7](../34/07.md), [13](../34/13.md)), Jacob’s sons held everyone in the city responsible for the crime that their ruler’s son had committed ([verses 25-29](../34/25.md)). If that is not clear, you could put that information in a footnote. Make sure that your translation of **they** does not refer to Jacob’s sons. Alternate translation: [They did that because that was where Shechem had disgraced their sister] or [to get revenge for the shameful thing that had been done to their sister there]

text: They took their flocks and herds and donkeys, and everything else in the city or in the field.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **donkeys** in Genesis [32:15](../32/15.md).

text: They carried off all their possessions and women and children, and they plundered everything in their houses.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **plundered** in [verse 27](../34/27.md). Alternate translation: [They carried away all the valuable things the people of Shechem had owned, including everything that was in their houses. They also captured all their women and children] or [They took away everything that was valuable and also captured all the children and women. They seized and took away everything that was in the houses]

text: Then Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, “You have brought trouble upon me by making me a stench to the Canaanites and Perizzites, the people of this land. We are few in number; if they unite against me and attack me, I and my household will be destroyed.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Later when they came home, Jacob scolded Simeon and Levi by saying]
Alternate translation: [You have caused me serious problems] or [You have put me in great danger]

The idiom **making me stink** means Jacob’s sons had caused him to have a very bad reputation, so that people would hate him and his family. Some languages have a similar idiom that fits well here. Also see how you translated **the Canaanites** and **the Perizzites** in Genesis [13:7](../13/07.md); [15:20–21](../15/20.md). There were other people groups also living in the land, but these two groups are the ones being emphasized here. Alternate translation: [by causing the people who live in this land to despise us, including the Canaanites and Perizzites!] or [by causing the Canaanites and Perizzites who live in this land to hate me]

The words “I,” “me,” and **my** refer in this verse to all of Jacob’s family; he uses these pronouns because he is the leader of his family. Alternate translation: [We only have a few men to defend us]
Make sure your use of the pronouns **me** or “us” fits with the way you translate the rest of this sentence. Alternate translation: [so if they all join forces against me and attack me]
Alternate translation: [then I and my family will be killed!] or [they will kill us and the rest of my household!]

text: But they replied, “Should he have treated our sister like a prostitute?”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [But Simeon and Levi replied angrily]

This rhetorical question shows Simeon and Levi’s anger and emphasizes that Shechem was wrong to do what he did and implies that he (and his city) deserved justice. Alternate translation: [He should not have treated our sister as a prostitute!]

text: Then God said to Jacob, “Arise, go up to Bethel, and settle there. Build an altar there to the God who appeared to you when you fled from your brother Esau.”

translation_challenges.note: Translate this quote margin in a way that is natural in your language and that fits with what God says. Alternate translation: [Then God told Jacob]
Alternate translation: [Get packed]

The verb **go up** reflects the fact that the town of Bethel is higher in elevation than the city of Shechem; it does not refer to the direction they were going, which was south. Many translations leave **up** implied (to prevent confusion). Alternate translation: [and travel to the town of Bethel and live there]
See how you translated **altar** in Genesis [33:20](../33/20.md).
Make sure it is clear in your translation that God is referring to himself as he speaks here to Jacob. Alternate translation: [to me as the God] or [to me, the God]
See how you translated **appeared** in Genesis [26:2](../26/02.md), [24](../26/24.md). Alternate translation: [who came to you there] or [who introduced myself to you there]
See how you translated “flee” in Genesis [31:20–21](../31/20.md), [27](../31/27.md).
Alternate translation: [from the anger of your brother Esau]

text: So Jacob told his household and all who were with him, “Get rid of the foreign gods that are among you. Purify yourselves and change your garments.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [So Jacob told the members of his family]

This included Jacob’s servants and the people (women and children) whom his sons had just captured from the city of Shechem (Genesis [34:29](../34/29.md)). You could put some of that information in a footnote.

By **foreign gods**, Jacob means the idols that came to the Jews from the non-Hebrew people with whom the Jews had dwelt and even intermarried. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. See how you translated “idols” and **gods** in Genesis [31:19](../31/19.md), [30](../31/30.md), [32](../31/32.md). Alternate translation: [Get rid of the idols you have that pagan ethnic groups worship] or [Give up the idols that you have from foreigners]
Alternate translation: [and dress in clean clothes]

text: Then let us arise and go to Bethel. I will build an altar there to God, who answered me in my day of distress. He has been with me wherever I have gone.”

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **get up** in [verse 1](../35/01.md). Alternate translation: [Then we must pack up our things] or [Then we must leave here]
See how you translated **go up** in [verse 1](../35/01.md). Alternate translation: [and go to the town of Bethel]

The Hebrew text has **I** here, but probably also implies that others in Jacob’s household would help him build the altar. Also see how you translated **make an altar** in [verse 1](../35/01.md). Alternate translation: [where I will build an altar to worship God] or [There I will build an altar and worship God]
Alternate translation: [because he answered me] or [who granted my prayers for help]

The phrase “In the day of” is used here as an idiom that could refer to the time when Jacob was fleeing from Esau, or it could be more general and also include other times when Jacob was suffering, such as the years he worked for Laban. Alternate translation: [during the days when I was in trouble]

See how you translated the idiom **with me** in Genesis [31:5](../31/05.md), where it also means that God is not only present with him but also helps him and takes care of him. Alternate translation: [He has always stayed with me and taken care of me]
Alternate translation: [everywhere that I have gone]

text: So they gave Jacob all their foreign gods and all their earrings, and Jacob buried them under the oak near Shechem.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then they gave Jacob] or [Then they turned over to Jacob]

See how you translated **foreign gods** in [verse 2](../35/02.md). You could translate this differently here since this is the second time they are mentioned in this paragraph. Alternate translation: [all the pagan gods that they had with them]

The implication is that these earrings were part of their idol worship and may have had images of their idols on them. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and the earrings they wore on their ears]
Alternate translation: [Then Jacob hid everything in the ground] or [Then Jacob hid all those things in the ground]

See how you translated a different Hebrew word that is also translated **terebinth tree** or “oak tree” in Genesis [12:6](../12/06.md); [13:18](../13/18.md); [14:13](../14/13.md); [18:1](../18/01.md). Another Hebrew word in Genesis [35:8](../35/08.md) is also translated as “oak.” Alternate translation: [a oak tree]

text: As they set out, a terror from God fell over the surrounding cities, so that they did not pursue Jacob’s sons.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then they all left there and started traveling]

The Hebrew word “Elohim” probably means **God** in this phrase (as it usually does in the Bible); most English versions translate it that way here. Or it could be an adjective that modifies “dread/terror” and means “great/deep dread/terror” (similar to Genesis [23:6](../23/06.md), [30:8](../30/08.md)). See how you translated **dread** in Genesis [9:2](../09/02.md). Alternate translation: [and God caused the people in the nearby cities to be afraid, so that] or [and God made the people in the nearby cities so afraid that]

text: There Jacob built an altar, and he called that place El-bethel, because it was there that God had revealed Himself to Jacob as he fled from his brother.

translation_challenges.note: Consider again how you translated **altar** throughout the book of Genesis. See [8:20](../08/20.md); [12:7–8](../12/07.md); [13:4](../13/04.md), [18](../13/18.md); [22:9](../22/09.md); [26:25](../26/25.md); [33:20](../33/20.md); [35:1](../35/01.md), [3](../35/03.md), [7](../35/07.md). Alternate translation: [There he built an altar] or [Then he built an altar there]
Alternate translation: [and he named that place] or [and he named it]
Alternate translation: [because it was at Bethel that]

See how you translated **from the presence of** in [verse 1](../35/01.md). Alternate translation: [from the anger of his brother]

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **nurse** in Genesis [24:59](../24/59.md).
Alternate translation: [and her body was buried by Jacob in the ground] or [They buried her body in the ground]

Alternate translation: [in the valley below the town of Bethel] or [at a place south of the town of Bethel]

See how you translated a similar phrase (“under the terebinth/oak tree”) in [verse 4](../35/04.md). Many translations translate this phrase the same way in both places (“under an oak tree”), even though different Hebrew words are used for the type of tree. Also, for some languages it is more natural to put this phrase before the previous phrase and say, “at the base of an oak tree, below/near the town of Bethel.” Alternate translation: [beside an oak tree] or [at the foot of an oak tree]

**So he called its name** could mean: (1) that Jacob was the one who named the place. See how you translated a similar clause in Genesis [31:38](../31/38.md). Alternate translation: [and showed his goodness toward him]

Alternate translation: [Rather, your name will also be Israel!] or [Rather, you will also have the name Israel!]

It may be necessary to translate this phrase in different ways, depending on the context.

Alternate translation: [Your descendants will become a large people group. In fact, many ethnic groups will descend from you] or [Your descendants will become many ethnic groups]

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **went up from** in Genesis [17:22](../17/22.md). Alternate translation: [Then God left Jacob there where he had been speaking to him]

See [12:8](../12/08.md); [13:3](../13/03.md); [28:19](../28/19.md); [31:13](../31/13.md); [35:1](../35/01.md), [3](../35/03.md), [7](../35/07.md), [15](../35/15.md), [16](../35/16.md). Alternate translation: [Then they left the town of Bethel] or [Later Jacob and his family moved on from the town of Bethel]

Alternate translation: [the midwife told her] or [the baby was born and the midwife who was helping her deliver exclaimed to her]
Alternate translation: [Do not worry]
Alternate translation: [You now have another boy!] or [You just gave birth to another son]

translation_challenges.note: Some translations use an idiom here, for example, “as she was taking her last breath” or “as her life was slipping/fading away,” but it is best to translate this in a way that preserves the biblical teaching that at death the soul or spirit leaves the body. The pronoun **his** refers to Jacob. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers.
The phrase “son of my right hand” is an idiom that means “favored son” or “son of strength.” Alternate translation: [named him Benjamin instead]

text: So Rachel died and was buried on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem).

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **was buried** in [verse 8](../35/08.md). Alternate translation: [After Rachel died, her body was buried by Jacob] or [After Rachel died, Jacob buried her body]
Alternate translation: [beside the road that goes to the town of Ephrath]
See how you translated a similar phrase (“which is Bethel”) in [verse 6](../35/06.md). Alternate translation: [which is also called Bethlehem] or [that is, Bethlehem]

Alternate translation: [over her burial place to show where it was] or [to show where her tomb was] or [to mark the place where he had buried her body]

text: About that time, Judah left his brothers and settled near a man named Hirah, an Adullamite.

translation_challenges.note: The phrase **And it happened** introduces a new episode here. Some translations leave it implied. Alternate translation: [Meanwhile] or [At this time]

In keeping with what is usual for his language and culture, the author is marking travel for change in elevation, **went down**. If this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [Judah departed from his brothers]

The word **Adullamite** refers to the fact that Hirah was from the town of Adullam; it is not the name of a people group. The town of Adullam was about 19 kilometers (12 miles) northwest of the city of Hebron ([37:14](../37/14.md)), and was lower in elevation, which is why the text says that Judah **went down** to get there. Alternate translation: [and lived in the town of Adullam near the home of a man from there] or [to the town of Adullam and lived near the home of a man from there]

text: There Judah saw the daughter of a Canaanite man named Shua, and he took her as a wife and slept with her.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated a similar idiom (“took a wife”) in Genesis [25:1](../25/01.md). Alternate translation: [and he took her as his wife]
See how you translated the idiom **went to** in Genesis [6:4](../06/04.md). Alternate translation: [Then he lay with her] or [Then he had sexual relations with her]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [and gave birth to a son]
Throughout Genesis, sometimes the father, sometimes the mother, and sometimes both are said to give their child his name. Alternate translation: [whom he named Er]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then she conceived again]

This could mean: (1) that Judah was at the town of Chezib when she gave birth to Shelah. Alternate translation: [When she gave birth to Shelah, Judah was in the town of Chezib] or (2) “It was in the town of Chezib that she gave birth to Shelah.” Alternate translation: [She was in Chezib when she gave birth to Shelah]

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated the phrase **took a wife for** in Genesis [21:21](../21/21.md). Alternate translation: [Years later, Judah chose a wife named Tamar for his firstborn son Er]

translation_challenges.note: Some languages leave **the firstborn of Judah** implied here since Er was already called the firstborn in [verse 6](../38/06.md). The Hebrew text repeats that information here to emphasize Er’s relationship to Judah in the following events.

The Hebrew text does not specify what Er had done wrong, so neither should your translation. See how you translated the idiom **in the eyes of Yahweh** in Genesis [6:8](../06/08.md). Alternate translation: [Er … did something that Yahweh judged to be evil]
Alternate translation: [so Yahweh took his life]

text: Then Judah said to Onan, “Sleep with your brother’s wife. Perform your duty as her brother-in-law and raise up offspring for your brother.”

translation_challenges.note: The author assumes that readers will know that the Israelites practiced the custom of Levirate marriage, which meant that if a man died without any children, it was his oldest brother’s duty to marry his widow. That way, they could produce a son who would carry on the deceased man’s family line and inherit his estate (See: [Deuteronomy 25:5–6](../../deu/25/05.md)). You could say that explicitly if that would be helpful to your readers.
Alternate translation: [so that you fulfill your duty to her as her brother-in-law]
Alternate translation: [and produce children with her]
Alternate translation: [to carry on the name of your brother Er]

text: But Onan knew that the offspring would not belong to him; so whenever he would sleep with his brother’s wife, he would spill his seed on the ground so that he would not produce offspring for his brother.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [But Onan knew that the children they would have together would not belong to him]
Alternate translation: [So every time]
Alternate translation: [he lay with] or [he had physical relations with]

Alternate translation: [so that he would not have offspring for his brother] or [to keep her from getting pregnant and having any offspring for his brother]

Alternate translation: [and disguised herself as a prostitute] or [to disguise herself]

Alternate translation: [After all]

Alternate translation: [but you could not find her]

Alternate translation: [someone said to Judah] or [someone informed Judah]
Consider again how you translated **daughter-in-law** in the book of Genesis. See [11:31](../11/31.md); [38:11](../38/11.md), [16](../38/16.md), [24](../38/24.md).
