text: So Pharaoh asked them, “Can we find anyone like this man, in whom the Spirit of God abides?”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [So Pharaoh said to his officials]

Pharaoh uses a rhetorical question here to emphasize that no one is more qualified than Joseph. Consider whether it is better in your language to translate this quote using a question or a statement. Alternate translation: [It is obvious that we will never find a man as qualified as Joseph]

The Hebrew text is ambiguous here. It could mean: (1) “who has God’s Spirit in him” or “whom God’s Spirit guides” or (2) “who has a divine spirit in him” or “who has a spirit of the gods in him.” Most translations follow the first interpretation, since Joseph had just talked to Pharaoh about God ([verses 16](../41/16.md), [28](../41/28.md), [32](../41/32.md)) and Pharaoh acknowledges God in [verse 39](../41/39.md).

text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Since God has made all this known to you, there is no one as discerning and wise as you.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then he turned to Joseph and said]
Alternate translation: [God has revealed to you what he is going to do, so]

See how you translated **discerning and wise** in [verse 33](../41/33.md). Alternate translation: [no one else is as insightful as you are and knows what to do in this situation] or [… or knows how to manage this situation wisely]

text: You shall be in charge of my house, and all my people are to obey your commands. Only with regard to the throne will I be greater than you.”

translation_challenges.note: The phrase **my house** refers here to Pharaoh’s household and all the other people he rules as king. Alternate translation: [So I am putting you in charge of my household and my country] or [So I am giving you authority over the people in my palace and the rest of my country]

Consider whether you have a similar idiom in your language or if you need to say this without an idiom. Alternate translation: [so that all the people in my kingdom must do whatever you say] or [so that all the people I reign over will respect and obey whatever you tell them to do]

In this context, **the throne** refers to Pharaoh’s position as the king. Make sure that is clear in your translation. Alternate translation: [Only I who sit on the throne as king will have more authority than you] or [Only I who am king will …]

text: Pharaoh also told Joseph, “I hereby place you over all the land of Egypt.”

translation_challenges.note: Some languages leave **Joseph** or even this entire quote margin implied here, since Pharaoh is still talking to the same person. Alternate translation: [Pharaoh added]
The word **See** emphasizes what Pharaoh says next. Alternate translation: [Look I now put you in charge of] or [I am now appointing you to be the supervisor over]
Alternate translation: [the whole land of Egypt]

text: Then Pharaoh removed the signet ring from his finger, put it on Joseph’s finger, clothed him in garments of fine linen, and placed a gold chain around his neck.

translation_challenges.note: The signet ring was the identification ring that the king used to seal official documents. See how you translated **signet** in Genesis [38:18](../38/18.md). Alternate translation: [Then Pharaoh took off his royal identification ring] or [Then Pharaoh took from his finger the ring that he used to seal letters with his mark]
The signet ring showed that Joseph represented Pharaoh and had his complete authority.

The Hebrew word for **fine linen** refers to a special kind of white cloth that was woven out of flax and had a fine texture. Clothes made from linen were expensive and were worn by the king and high officials. If linen is not known in your language area, you could be more general and refer to expensive, high-quality clothes. Alternate translation: [He also had Joseph put on fine linen robes] or [He also gave Joseph high-quality robes to wear]
Alternate translation: [and put a collar made of gold around his neck] or [and put around his neck a necklace made of gold]

text: He had Joseph ride in his second chariot, with men calling out before him, “Bow the knee!” So he placed him over all the land of Egypt.

translation_challenges.note: A chariot is a cart with two or four wheels that was pulled by one or more horses. It was used as transportation and was especially used in battles. Translate this in a way that fits with this description. It may be helpful to include a picture of a chariot in your translation. Alternate translation: [in a royal horse-drawn cart as his second-in-command] or [in the horse-drawn cart that showed he was the second highest ruler in the country]

Make sure the way you translate **shouted** does not sound angry. Rather they were calling out loudly enough for people to hear them. Alternate translation: [As he rode, heralds walked in the streets ahead of him calling out to everyone]

The Hebrew text is ambiguous here. It could be: (1) a transliteration of an Egyptian word that means “Bow down in reverence/respect!” or “Make way for the king’s appointed one!” or “Welcome/Honor your new leader!” which is what people would be told to do to honor an important person; or (2) a combination of Hebrew words that means “This is the father of the king!”, which is similar to what Joseph says in Genesis [45:8](../45/08.md).

See how you translated a similar sentence in [verse 41](../41/41.md). Alternate translation: [So Pharaoh put Joseph in charge of] or [In that way, Pharaoh officially installed Joseph to be the manager over]
Alternate translation: [the whole land of Egypt]

text: And Pharaoh declared to Joseph, “I am Pharaoh, but without your permission, no one in all the land of Egypt shall lift his hand or foot.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [I, Pharaoh, hereby decree that]

The phrase “will not lift his hand or foot” is exaggeration that is used to emphasize Joseph’s authority. Consider whether or not it is clear and natural to do that here in your language. Alternate translation: [no one throughout the entire country of Egypt may do anything unless you tell them to do it!] or [throughout the entire country of Egypt, everyone must only do what you tell them to do!]

text: Pharaoh gave Joseph the name Zaphenath-paneah, and he gave him Asenath daughter of Potiphera, priest of On, to be his wife. And Joseph took charge of all the land of Egypt.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then Pharaoh called Joseph by the Egyptian name]

Potiphera was a pagan priest, and he led people in worshiping the Egyptians’ gods, not Yahweh. See how you translated **priest** in Genesis [14:18](../14/18.md). Alternate translation: [and he gave him a woman named Asenath to be his wife. She was the daughter of Potiphera, who was a priest at the temple at the city of On]
Alternate translation: [Then Joseph started going around all over the land of Egypt] or [Then Joseph started his work and traveled throughout the land of Egypt]

text: Now Joseph was thirty years old when he entered the service of Pharaoh king of Egypt. And Joseph left Pharaoh’s presence and traveled throughout the land of Egypt.

translation_challenges.note: Consider what is the best way to begin this new paragraph in your language.
This phrase refers to when Joseph stood before Pharaoh and was commissioned to serve as the second-highest ruler in Egypt. Alternate translation: [when he had that audience with]
Alternate translation: [and traveled throughout the entire country of Egypt doing his work] or [and began traveling from place to place throughout …]

text: During the seven years of abundance, the land brought forth bountifully.

translation_challenges.note: Compare how you translated **seven years of abundance** in [verse 34](../41/34.md). Alternate translation: [During the seven years when food was abundant] or [For seven years the harvests were plentiful and]

The idiom **by the handfuls** refers here to large amounts of grain. Consider whether your language has a similar idiom you could use here. Alternate translation: [the land produced large amounts of grain] or [the people harvested large amounts of grain from the land]

text: During those seven years, Joseph collected all the excess food in the land of Egypt and stored it in the cities. In every city he laid up the food from the fields around it.

translation_challenges.note: When the Bible says that a leader such as Joseph did something, it often means that he had it done by people under his authority. Decide whether you want to include this information in your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [So Joseph told the supervisors under him to collect] or [So Joseph had his helpers gather]

See how you translated **all the food** in [verse 35](../41/35.md). Alternate translation: [all the extra food that was produced in the land of Egypt during those seven years] or [all the extra grain that people produced during those seven years in the land of Egypt]
Alternate translation: [and he had them store that grain in the cities]

Consider what phrase order is best for this sentence in your language. Alternate translation: [The food that people had harvested from the fields, he had his supervisors stockpile in the nearby cities] or [In each city he had them store the food that people had harvested from the nearby fields]

text: So Joseph stored up grain in such abundance, like the sand of the sea, that he stopped keeping track of it; for it was beyond measure.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated “store/stockpile” in [verse 35](../41/35.md). Alternate translation: [Joseph had his helpers store up]

See how you translated “as the sand of the sea” in Genesis [32:12](../32/12.md) and a similar phrase in Genesis [22:17](../22/17.md). Alternate translation: [so much grain that it looked as plentiful as grains of sand beside the sea] or [… as plentiful as the grains of sand on the beach]
Alternate translation: [In fact, there was so much that] or [In fact, it was so plentiful that after a while]

It was probably Joseph’s helpers who measured the grain and kept records of it. See how you handled this at the beginning of this verse. Alternate translation: [he had them stop keeping track of it] or [they had to stop writing down how much there was]
Alternate translation: [because there was so much that they could no longer record it]

text: Before the years of famine arrived, two sons were born to Joseph by Asenath daughter of Potiphera, priest of On.

translation_challenges.note: Consider what is the best way to change topics and begin this new paragraph in your language. Alternate translation: [Now it so happened that before the seven years of famine came]

See how you translated **Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera, the priest of On** in [verse 45](../41/45.md). Alternate translation: [Joseph had two sons with his wife Asenath, a daughter of Potiphera, who was a priest in the city of On] or [Joseph and his wife Asenath had two sons. Remember that Asenath was a daughter of Potiphera, a priest in the city of On]

text: Joseph named the firstborn Manasseh, saying, “God has made me forget all my hardship and all my father’s household.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [his first son]
If you include the meaning of the name **Manasseh** in your translation or in a footnote, it should fit with the way you translate **forget** in the following clause.

By **made me forget**, the author does not mean that Joseph had lost his memory of these things, but rather, that God had blessed him so much that it helped him stop thinking about those things. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [because he said, “God has caused me to stop thinking about]
Alternate translation: [all my hardships and about]
Alternate translation: [how much I have missed all of my family back home]
See how you translated the idiom **called the name of** in [Gen 21:3](../21/03.md).

text: And the second son he named Ephraim, saying, “God has made me fruitful in the land of my affliction.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [And Joseph named his second son]
If you include the meaning of Ephraim’s name in your translation or in a footnote, it should fit with the way you translate **fruitful** in the following clause.
Consider again how you translated the idiom **fruitful** in the book of Genesis. See [17:6](../17/06.md); [26:22](../26/22.md); [41:52](../41/52.md).

text: When the seven years of abundance in the land of Egypt came to an end,

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **the seven years of abundance** in [verses 34](../41/34.md) and [47](../41/47.md), and a similar phrase in [verse 29](../41/29.md). Alternate translation: [Finally the seven years when food was abundant]

For some languages it is better to put this phrase earlier in the sentence and say, “Finally the seven years were over when food was plentiful in the country of Egypt. Alternate translation: [came to an end]

text: the seven years of famine began, just as Joseph had said. And although there was famine in every country, there was food throughout the land of Egypt.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then the seven years of famine began]
Alternate translation: [just as Joseph had predicted would happen] or [which is exactly what Joseph had said would happen]
Alternate translation: [The severe food shortage began to affect all countries]
Alternate translation: [but everywhere in the land of Egypt] or [but throughout the entire land of Egypt]
In this context, **bread** refers to all food in general. Alternate translation: [there was still plenty of food stored up]

text: When extreme hunger came to all the land of Egypt and the people cried out to Pharaoh for food, he told all the Egyptians, “Go to Joseph and do whatever he tells you.”

translation_challenges.note: The phrase **all the land** refers here to the people living in Egypt. Consider whether or not you need to make that explicit in your language. Alternate translation: [Then all the people in the land of Egypt began to suffer from the famine, so]
Alternate translation: [they begged Pharaoh for food] or [they pleaded with Pharaoh to give them food]
Alternate translation: [So King Pharaoh told them] or [So he told them]
Alternate translation: [Go ask Joseph for food] or [You must go to Joseph and ask him for help]
Alternate translation: [and do whatever he tells you to do]

text: When the famine had spread over all the land, Joseph opened up all the storehouses and sold grain to the Egyptians; for the famine was severe in the land of Egypt.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Since the famine had spread throughout the whole country] or [Since the severe food shortage was affecting the entire country]

See how you translated [verses 48](../41/48.md) and [49](../41/49.md), where Joseph is said to do something that he had his helpers do. Alternate translation: [Joseph ordered the supervisors under him to open up]
Alternate translation: [all the storage barns where grain was being stored]
Alternate translation: [and they started selling the grain to the people of Egypt]
Alternate translation: [Then the famine kept getting more and more severe]
Alternate translation: [throughout the land of Egypt] or [throughout their country]

text: And every nation came to Joseph in Egypt to buy grain, because the famine was severe over all the earth.

translation_challenges.note: This phrase refers to the people living on the earth. Consider whether or not you need to make that explicit in your language. See how you translated a similar metonymy (“all the land”) in [verse 55](../41/55.md). Alternate translation: [In fact, people from all over the earth]
Alternate translation: [started traveling to Egypt to buy food from Joseph]

For some languages it is clearer or more natural to put this clause near the beginning of [verse 57](../41/57.md) and say, “In fact, the famine was/became so severe/terrible in/throughout the entire/whole world that people started coming/traveling to Egypt from all over the world to buy grain from Joseph.” See how you translated “severe/terrible” in [verse 56](../41/56.md). Alternate translation: [because the food shortage was so severe throughout the entire world]

text: When Jacob learned that there was grain in Egypt, he said to his sons, “Why are you staring at one another?”

translation_challenges.note: This verse begins a new episode which overlaps in time with some of what was happening in [chapter 41](../41/01.md). Consider what is the best way to begin this episode in your language. Alternate translation: [Meanwhile in the land of Canaan, when Jacob learned that there was grain for sale in the country of Egypt] or [… when Jacob found out that he could buy grain in Egypt]
Alternate translation: [he asked his sons]

Jacob uses this rhetorical question to get his sons to take action and do what he says next. Consider what is the best way to communicate that in your language. Alternate translation: [What are you waiting for?] or [Do not just sit here staring at each other!] or [Do not just stand there doing nothing!]

text: “Look,” he added, “I have heard that there is grain in Egypt. Go down there and buy some for us, so that we may live and not die.”

translation_challenges.note: For some languages it is more natural to omit the quote margin here, because the same person (Jacob) is still talking to the same people (his sons). Alternate translation: [Then he added]
Alternate translation: [Look]
Alternate translation: [I learned] or [Someone told me]
Alternate translation: [that there is much grain for sale in the country of Egypt] or [that the country of Egypt has a lot of grain that people can buy]
Make sure that the way you translate Jacob’s command to his sons does not sound rude or harsh. Alternate translation: [So I want you to go there] or [So please go down there]
Alternate translation: [and buy some grain for us all]
Alternate translation: [so that we will survive] or [so that we will stay alive]
Alternate translation: [and not die from hunger]

text: So ten of Joseph’s brothers went down to buy grain from Egypt.

translation_challenges.note: These ten brothers were older than Joseph and had different mothers than he did. Also, the verb **went down** refers to the fact that Egypt was lower in elevation than the land of Canaan. It is also located southwest of Canaan. See how you translated “go down” in [verse 2](../42/02.md) and **went down** in Genesis [12:10](../12/10.md).

text: But Jacob did not send Joseph’s brother Benjamin with his brothers, for he said, “I am afraid that harm might befall him.”

translation_challenges.note: Benjamin was younger than Joseph and had the same mother (Rachel) and father.
Alternate translation: [with his other brothers]

For some languages it is more natural to put this clause first in this verse and say, “But Jacob was concerned that harm might come to Joseph’s younger brother Benjamin, so he did not send him with the rest of his brothers to Egypt.” Alternate translation: [because Jacob thought that he might be harmed] or [because he was concerned that something terrible might happen to him]

text: So the sons of Israel were among those who came to buy grain, since the famine had also spread to the land of Canaan.

translation_challenges.note: If it is not clear that **Israel** ([verse 5](../42/05.md)) and “Jacob” ([verse 4](../42/04.md)) refer to the same person, you could include the name Jacob here in your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [The sons of Israel that is, Jacob] or [So the sons of Jacob, who was also called Israel]
Alternate translation: [came to Egypt]
Alternate translation: [along with many other people who were going there] or [along with many other travelers]
See how you translated **because the famine** in Genesis [41:57](../41/57.md). Alternate translation: [because the extreme food shortage] or [because the extreme lack of food]
Alternate translation: [was also affecting everyone in the land of Canaan] or [was also affecting the entire land of Canaan]

text: Now Joseph was the ruler of the land; he was the one who sold grain to all its people. So when his brothers arrived, they bowed down before him with their faces to the ground.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Since Joseph was the administrator over the land of Egypt]
The Hebrew text is ambiguous here. It could mean: (1) “the country of Egypt,” which is what it means earlier in [verse 6](../42/06.md); or (2) “the earth/world.”
So/Then Joseph’s brothers also came/went

See how you translated “bow down” in Genesis [37:7](../37/07.md), [9-10](../37/09.md). Alternate translation: [before him like everyone else and bowed down with their foreheads toward the ground to show him respect] or [to him and prostrated themselves before him to show respect]

text: And when Joseph saw his brothers, he recognized them, but he treated them as strangers and spoke harshly to them. “Where have you come from?” he asked. “From the land of Canaan,” they replied. “We are here to buy food.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Joseph immediately recognized his brothers]

For some languages it is better to divide the first sentence in this verse into shorter sentences. Alternate translation: [but he treated them like strangers] or [But he pretended that he did not know them]
Alternate translation: [and spoke to them in a harsh way] or [In fact, he spoke to them roughly]
Alternate translation: [and questioned them] or [and demanded]
Alternate translation: [Where are you from?]

For some languages it is necessary to begin with a respectful title or form of address when someone talks to a person of high status like Joseph. See how Joseph’s brothers address him in [verse 10](../42/10.md). Alternate translation: [Sir, we came from the land of Canaan to buy some grain] or [Sir, we are from the land of Canaan and we came to buy some grain]

text: Although Joseph recognized his brothers, they did not recognize him.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Although Joseph recognized his brothers, they did not know who he was]

text: Joseph remembered his dreams about them and said, “You are spies! You have come to see if our land is vulnerable.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [about them long ago]
Alternate translation: [so he told them]
Alternate translation: [You are spying on our country!]
Alternate translation: [The reason you came here is]
Alternate translation: [to find out where our country is vulnerable!]

text: “Not so, my lord,” they replied. “Your servants have come to buy food.

translation_challenges.note: Make sure your translation of this phrase sounds polite. In some cultures it is rude to say **No** too directly. See how you translated a similar phrase in Genesis [23:11](../23/11.md). Alternate translation: [No, sir]

The brothers referred to themselves as **your servants** to show respect to Joseph and to acknowledge his high position. Translate this phrase in a polite way that shows respect toward Joseph. Alternate translation: [but rather we come before you humbly] or [Rather, we are just humble men who have come here]
Alternate translation: [only to buy some food]

text: We are all sons of one man. Your servants are honest men, not spies.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [the sons of the same man]
Alternate translation: [We are trustworthy people who highly respect you. We are not spies] or [We are humble, honest people, not spies]

text: “No,” he told them. “You have come to see if our land is vulnerable.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then Joseph replied] or [But he accused them]

Different languages use “yes” and “no” in different ways, depending on the context. Do what is accurate and natural in this context in your language. Also see how you translated **No** in Genesis [18:15](../18/15.md).
See how you translated this phrase in [verse 9](../42/09.md). Alternate translation: [to find out where our country is vulnerable!]

text: But they answered, “Your servants are twelve brothers, the sons of one man in the land of Canaan. The youngest is now with our father, and one is no more.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then they responded]
Alternate translation: [Sir, there are twelve of us brothers]
Alternate translation: [We are all sons of the same man] or [We all have the same father]
Alternate translation: [who lives in the land of Canaan] or [and we live in the land of Canaan]
The word **behold** calls attention to what the brothers say next. Some translations leave it implied. Alternate translation: [In fact, our youngest brother]
Alternate translation: [is presently back at home with our father] or [is there with our father right now]
Alternate translation: [but the other one]

In this context, **is not** is an idiom that means “has died.” Consider whether or not your language has a similar idiom that would fit well here. Alternate translation: [is no more] or [is no longer with us]

text: Then Joseph declared, “Just as I said, you are spies!

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then Joseph accused them] or [Then Joseph responded]

Consider whether it is more natural in your language to translate the embedded quote **You are spies** as a direct or indirect quote. Alternate translation: [What I told you is right You are spying on our country!] or [I was right when I said that you are secretly gathering information about our country!]

text: And this is how you will be tested: As surely as Pharaoh lives, you shall not leave this place unless your youngest brother comes here.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [In this way]

See how you translated other vows in Genesis [14:22](../14/22.md) and [21:23–24](../21/23.md). Alternate translation: [As certain as King Pharaoh lives, I vow that]
Alternate translation: [you will definitely not leave] or [I will not let you leave]
Alternate translation: [from here]

Alternate translation: [to get your youngest brother and bring him here]

It may be necessary to translate this phrase in different ways, depending on the context. Alternate translation: [After three days, Joseph said to them]

Alternate translation: [I urge you to allow me your servant to be the one to stay here] or [sir, I urge you to let me stay here]

Do what is best in your language in each context. Alternate translation: [as a slave for you] or [and be your servant]
Alternate translation: [to take the place of]

text: For how can I go back to my father without the boy? I could not bear to see the misery that would overwhelm him.”

Alternate translation: [I do not want to see]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [When Joseph heard what Judah said, he was no longer able to]
Alternate translation: [hide his feelings]

text: Joseph said to his brothers, “I am Joseph! Is my father still alive?” But they were unable to answer him, because they were terrified in his presence.

translation_challenges.note: In this chapter, the word **brothers** refers to Joseph’s older brothers (from different mothers) and his younger brother (from the same mother). Alternate translation: [Then Joseph exclaimed to his brothers in their language]
Alternate translation: [I am Joseph, your brother!]

Joseph uses **my father** to emphasize his relationship with his father. Make sure your translation does not sound like he had a different father than his brothers. Alternate translation: [Is our father still alive?]
Alternate translation: [His brothers could not say a word]

Alternate translation: [I truly am your brother Joseph]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [do not be distressed]

It may be necessary to translate these idioms in different ways, depending on the context. Alternate translation: [or angry at yourselves]
Alternate translation: [that you sold me and caused me to be a slave here] or [for selling me as a slave]
Alternate translation: [because God sent me here]
Alternate translation: [before you got here]
Alternate translation: [to keep many people from dying]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [The past two years]

Alternate translation: [and for another five years it will be so bad that] or [and during the next five years it will be even worse, so that] or [and there will be five more years when]
Alternate translation: [there will be no plowing of fields or harvesting of crops]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [God caused me to come here]
Alternate translation: [before you got here]
Alternate translation: [so that you will have descendants living] or [to help you survive and have descendants]

Alternate translation: [by helping you stay live] or [by saving your lives]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [you are not the ones]
Alternate translation: [who brought me here]
Alternate translation: [but rather it was God who brought me] or [but rather God is the one who did it]

text: Now return quickly to my father and tell him, ‘This is what your son Joseph says: God has made me lord of all Egypt. Come down to me without delay.

translation_challenges.note: In this verse, the words **up** and **down** reflect the fact that Canaan was higher in elevation than Egypt. Many languages leave those words implied. Alternate translation: [Hurry up] or [Leave quickly and go back] or [Return quickly]
See how you translated **my father** in [verse 3](../45/03.md).
Consider whether it is best in your language to translate this embedded quote as a direct or indirect quote.

Consider whether it is best in your language to translate this doubly embedded quote (which continues through [verse 11](../45/11.md)) as a direct or indirect quote. He also says that you and your family may live in Goshen Province and that way you will live near him … He will provide for you there …” Alternate translation: [God has made me ruler over the entire country of Egypt]

For some languages it is more natural to put this clause first in this sentence and say, “So please do not take very long, but rather come down/here quickly to live near me.” Alternate translation: [and do not wait] or [and do not take very long to come]

text: You shall settle in the land of Goshen and be near me—you and your children and grandchildren, your flocks and herds, and everything you own.

translation_challenges.note: The pronouns **you** and **your** in this verse are singular, but Joseph’s message to his father includes the whole family. Alternate translation: [You and your family may live]

Alternate translation: [and that way you can be near me] or [That way you can live close to me]
Alternate translation: [as well as all your domestic animals]
Alternate translation: [and all your other belongings]

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [I will support you there]

The verb **become impoverished** can include losing livestock, other belongings, and the lives of their servants and family members. Alternate translation: [That way you and your extended family will not become poor and die] or [Please come so that the famine does not cause you and your family to lose everything you own and die]

text: Behold! You and my brother Benjamin can see that I, Joseph, am the one speaking with you.

translation_challenges.note: Make sure it is clear in your translation that Joseph’s message to his father was completed in [verse 11](../45/11.md), and that here in [verse 12](../45/12.md) he is talking directly to his brothers again. Alternate translation: [Now look] or [Then Joseph said to his brothers, Look!]

The word **eyes** is used figuratively here (and in the next phrase) to refer to the persons themselves; it also emphasizes the fact that they were seeing Joseph in person. Consider what is the best way to translate this phrase in your language. Alternate translation: [I can tell that all of you]

Here the phrase **my mouth** refers to Joseph himself; it also emphasizes the fact that it was Joseph himself who was talking to them. Consider what is the best way to translate this figure of speech in your language. Alternate translation: [can see that I Joseph am the one]

text: Tell my father about all my splendor in Egypt and everything you have seen. And bring my father down here quickly.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [So go and tell my father]
Alternate translation: [about my high position in Egypt] or [about how honored I am in Egypt]
See how you translated **down** in [verse 9](../45/09.md). Alternate translation: [Then hurry and bring him down here to me] or [Then quickly bring him here to me]

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated the idiom “fell on his neck” in Genesis [33:4](../33/04.md). Alternate translation: [Then Joseph hugged his brother Benjamin strongly]
Alternate translation: [and started crying because he was so happy]
Alternate translation: [Benjamin also cried as he hugged him back]

text: When the news reached Pharaoh’s house that Joseph’s brothers had come, Pharaoh and his servants were pleased.

translation_challenges.note: Consider whether it is better to use a direct or indirect quote here in your language.
Alternate translation: [it was pleasing to Pharaoh and all his officials] or [Pharaoh and all his officials were pleased]

text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Tell your brothers, ‘Do as follows: Load your animals and return to the land of Canaan.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Then Pharaoh told Joseph] or [Then Pharaoh gave these instructions to Joseph:]

These animals were donkeys (Genesis [43:18](../43/18.md), [44:3](../44/03.md)), not any other kind of animal. Also, consider whether it is better in your language to translate this embedded quote with a direct or indirect quote. Alternate translation: [to region of Canaan]

Alternate translation: [Then tell them to bring their father and their families back here to me]
Alternate translation: [I will give them]

Alternate translation: [Then Joseph gave them carts to use]

See how you translated **carts** in Genesis [45:19](../45/19.md), [21](../45/21.md), [27](../45/27.md).

See how you translated the idiom “walk/live before” in Genesis [17:1](../17/01.md) and [24:40](../24/40.md). You may need to translate it differently in different contexts. Alternate translation: [walked with according to his will] or [lived obediently in the presence of] or [obeyed]

The word **shepherding** includes guiding, protecting, and providing food and water, such as a shepherd would do for his sheep. Here it is used as a image that refers to God’s complete care of Israel throughout his life. Consider whether or not it is best in your language to use a similar image here. Alternate translation: [the same God who has watched over me]
Alternate translation: [from the beginning of my life until the present day]

text: the angel who has redeemed me from all harm—may He bless these boys. And may they be called by my name and the names of my fathers Abraham and Isaac, and may they grow into a multitude upon the earth.”

translation_challenges.note: Since Joseph’s sons were probably in their 20s, make sure your translation of this phrase does not sound like they were little **boys**. The Hebrew word for “boy” here can also be translated as “lad,” “servant,” or “young man,” depending on the context and who is speaking to whom. With that in mind, consider again how you translated this word in the book of Genesis. See [14:24](../14/24.md); [18:7](../18/07.md); [19:4](../19/04.md); [21:12](../21/12.md), [17-20](../21/17.md); [22:3](../22/03.md), [5](../22/05.md), [12](../22/12.md), [19](../22/19.md); [25:27](../25/27.md); [34:19](../34/19.md); [37:2](../37/02.md); [41:12](../41/12.md); [43:8](../43/08.md); [44:22](../44/22.md), [30-34](../44/30.md); [48:16](../48/16.md). Alternate translation: [I ask that he will cause these young men to prosper greatly]

Alternate translation: [so that my family name and the family name of my ancestors Abraham and Isaac will continue through them and so that they will have many descendants on the earth] or [I pray that they will have many descendants on the earth who will carry on the family name for me and for my forefathers Abraham and Isaac]

text: When Joseph saw that his father had placed his right hand on Ephraim’s head, he was displeased and took his father’s hand to move it from Ephraim’s head to Manasseh’s.

translation_challenges.note: See how you translated **placed** in [verse 14](../48/14.md).
Alternate translation: [it displeased him] or [he was unhappy about it]

text: “Not so, my father!” Joseph said. “This one is the firstborn; put your right hand on his head.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Not like that, Father. It is the other son who is my firstborn] or [That is the wrong one Father. The other one is my oldest son]
Alternate translation: [So you need to put your right hand on his head]

text: But his father refused. “I know, my son, I know!” he said. “He too shall become a people, and he too shall be great; nevertheless, his younger brother shall be greater than he, and his offspring shall become a multitude of nations.”

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [But his father refused to move his hands]
Alternate translation: [I know it my son, I know what I am doing] or [I know what I am doing, my son]

Consider what is the best way in your language to refer to Joseph’s firstborn in these two clauses. Alternate translation: [In fact, the descendants of your firstborn son will also become a ethnic group, and he will be a great man] or [In fact, your firstborn son will also be a important man, and he will be the ancestor of a people group]
Alternate translation: [However, his younger brother Ephraim will be even greater than he will be]
Make sure that your translation of this phrase refers to Ephraim’s descendants, not Manasseh’s. Alternate translation: [with many descendants, who]
Compare how you translated a similar phrase (“a community of peoples”) in [verse 4](../48/04.md). Alternate translation: [will become many ethnic groups]

text: So that day Jacob blessed them and said: “By you shall Israel pronounce this blessing: ‘May God make you like Ephraim and Manasseh.’” So he put Ephraim before Manasseh.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [and said]
Alternate translation: [When the people of Israel say a blessing over someone, they will use your names]
Alternate translation: [May God bless you] or [We ask God to make you great]
Alternate translation: [like he blessed Ephraim and Manasseh]
Alternate translation: [When he said that, he put Ephraim ahead of Manasseh] or [In that way, he made Ephraim greater than Manasseh]

text: Then Israel said to Joseph, “Look, I am about to die, but God will be with you and bring you back to the land of your fathers.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Next Israel spoke to Joseph. He said]
Alternate translation: [Look]
Alternate translation: [I will die soon]

The pronouns **you** and **your** are plural throughout this verse and probably refer to all Israel’s family, including Joseph, his brothers, and their descendants. Alternate translation: [but God will always stay with all of you and help you] or [but God will always stay with you and your brothers and all your descendants and help you]
Alternate translation: [He will also bring you back]
Alternate translation: [to the land that he gave to your forefathers]

text: And to you, as one who is above your brothers, I give the ridge of land that I took from the Amorites with my sword and bow.”

translation_challenges.note: The pronouns **you** and **your** shift to singular in [verse 22](../48/22.md), so use the singular form in your translation if your language marks that distinction.. Alternate translation: [And I bequeath to you as part of your inheritance]

Here, **Schechem** could refer to: (1) the city of Shechem. (2) a mountain ridge. This second interpretation comes from the meaning of the Hebrew word “shekem” (“shoulder”), which can be used as an image to refer to a mountain slope or ridge.
Alternate translation: [which is more land than I am giving to your brothers and]
Alternate translation: [which I took control of from] or [I took that land from]

For some languages it may be clearer to change the order of clauses in this verse and say, “Besides that, I hereby give you the city of Shechem, which I took/captured from the Amorites when I defeated them in battle. This is more land than I am giving to your brothers.” Also consider again how you translated **Amorites** in the book of Genesis. See [10:16](../10/16.md); [14:7](../14/07.md), [13](../14/13.md); [15:16](../15/16.md), [21](../15/21.md); [48:22](../48/22.md). Alternate translation: [the Amorites in battle using my sword and my bow]

text: Then Jacob called for his sons and said, “Gather around so that I can tell you what will happen to you in the days to come:

translation_challenges.note: Much of what Jacob says to his sons in [verses 1-27](../49/01.md) is Hebrew poetry, which is characterized by the use of parallelisms and metaphors to emphasize important points. Many translations put these verses in poetry format (starting here); many others use regular paragraph formatting. For a complete list of verses that some translations treat as poetry in the book of Genesis, see the introduction to the book. Alternate translation: [Gather yourselves together before me]
Alternate translation: [and I will declare to you] or [so that I can inform you]

Much of what Jacob prophesies in this chapter about his sons also applies to their descendants. Some translation teams may prefer to put that information in a footnote rather than make it explicit in the text. Also see how you translated **meet** in Genesis [42:4](../42/04.md), [38](../42/38.md).

In this context, this phrase refers to a period of years in the future. Consider what is the best way to communicate that in your language. Alternate translation: [in the days ahead] or [in future days]

text: Come together and listen, O sons of Jacob; listen to your father Israel.

translation_challenges.note: Make sure it is clear in your translation of this verse that Jacob is talking to his own sons and is referring to himself as both Jacob and as Israel. Also, for some languages it is more natural to put the address **sons of Jacob** first in [verse 2](../49/02.md), or even first in the quote (which begins in [verse 1](../49/01.md)).

This clause forms a parallelism with the previous clause to emphasize that Jacob wants his sons to listen to him carefully. Try to keep both halves of this parallelism in your translation, since each half has a slightly different focus. Alternate translation: [Pay attention to me, your father Israel]

text: Reuben, you are my firstborn, my might, and the beginning of my strength, excelling in honor, excelling in power.

translation_challenges.note: This phrase is used here as a euphemistic idiom that refers to Jacob’s ability to have children. Other languages may have a similar idiom. Translate this in a way that will not embarrass or offend listeners. Alternate translation: [the result of my fertility, and the first child I had as a young man] or [You are the first sign of my manhood and strength]
Alternate translation: [You had higher honor and authority than all your brothers]

text: Uncontrolled as the waters, you will no longer excel, because you went up to your father’s bed, onto my couch, and defiled it.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [However, you are uncontrollable] or [However, you are reckless]

Here Jacob compares Reuben’s reckless, uncontrolled sexual behavior to turbulent water that is out of control and destructive. Consider whether or not you have a similar comparison in your language that would fit well here. Alternate translation: [like a flood of water]
Alternate translation: [so you will no longer have your high position in our family] or [so you will no longer be first among your brothers]

This clause, along with the rest of the verse, is a euphemistic way of referring to Reuben committing adultery by sleeping with his father’s concubine (secondary wife) Bilhah (Genesis [35:22](../35/22.md)). Alternate translation: [because you got into my bed with my wife and dishonored me!] or [because you dishonored me by getting into my bed and committing adultery with my concubine]

Here Jacob repeats part of what he said in the previous clause, in order to emphasize Reuben’s sin against him and to communicate how upset he is about it. He may have still been talking to Reuben (switching from second to third person), or he may have been exclaiming about Reuben to himself and the rest of his sons.

text: Simeon and Levi are brothers; their swords are weapons of violence.

translation_challenges.note: In [verses 3-27](../49/03.md), Jacob sometimes refers to his sons using second person (“you”), and sometimes (as here) he uses third person (“they” or “he”). Consider whether or not it is better in your language to use second person throughout these verses, especially since Jacob is talking to his sons who are right there with him. Also, some languages have dual pronouns that fit well in [verses 5-7](../49/05.md). Alternate translation: [As for Simeon and Levi, they]

This phrase is used here as an idiom that emphasizes the fact that Simeon and Levi thought alike and acted together to do evil things. Alternate translation: [are close brothers] or [are partners in crime] or [do evil things together]

Make sure in your translation that the pronouns you use here (and in [verses 6-7](../49/06.md)) fit with the way you translated the beginning of this verse. Alternate translation: [They use their weapons to do violent things together]

text: May I never enter their council; may I never join their assembly. For they kill men in their anger, and hamstring oxen on a whim.

translation_challenges.note: Here Jacob uses the phrase **my soul** to refer to himself and to emphasize how strongly he feels about what he is saying. Consider what is the best way to communicate that in your language. Alternate translation: [Do not ever let me] or [May I never]

In [verses 5-7](../49/05.md), Jacob is probably referring to the time when Simeon and Levi killed all the males in the city of Shechem out of revenge (Genesis [34:25–26](../34/25.md), [30](../34/30.md)). Jacob was very upset that they did that. Alternate translation: [take part in their evil plans] or [participate with them when you plan evil things!]

This clause forms a parallelism with the previous clause and emphasizes that Jacob is upset and does not want to participate with these two sons in their evil behavior. Consider what is the best way to translate that in your language. Alternate translation: [Do not let my honor be associated with your evil plans] or [I never want to be linked with their evil plans]

The phrase **a man** probably refers collectively here to all the men whom these two sons killed in the city of Shechem (Genesis [34:25–26](../34/25.md), [30](../34/30.md)). Alternate translation: [because you became angry and murdered many men]

This may have happened during the time that Simeon and Levi took revenge on the people of Shechem. Alternate translation: [and just to please yourselves, you crippled some oxen so they could not walk] or [and you cut the leg tendons of some oxen just for the fun of it]

text: Cursed be their anger, for it is strong, and their wrath, for it is cruel! I will disperse them in Jacob and scatter them in Israel.

translation_challenges.note: Consider what is the best way to translate this parallelism in your language. Also, consider again how you translated “cursed” in the book of Genesis. See [3:14](../03/14.md) (and note), 17; [4:11](../04/11.md); [5:29](../05/29.md); [8:21](../08/21.md); [9:25](../09/25.md); [12:3](../12/03.md); [27:12–13](../27/12.md), [29](../27/29.md); [49:7](../49/07.md). Alternate translation: [May God curse them for your intense anger and your malicious fury!] or [I ask God to punish them for being so intensely angry and malicious!]

The last half of [verse 7](../49/07.md) specifies how Jacob is asking God to curse Simeon and Levi. Alternate translation: [I ask God to disperse them and their descendants] or [May he cause them and their descendants to be spread out]
In this context, the name **Jacob** refers to his family and especially his descendants. Alternate translation: [among the family of Jacob]

The clauses “I will divide …” and “I will scatter …” form a parallelism that emphasizes the way Jacob is asking God to curse Simeon and Levi. If possible, it is best to keep both parts of a parallelism in your translation. Alternate translation: [Yes, I will]

Consider again how you translated **scatter** in the book of Genesis. See [10:18](../10/18.md), [32](../10/32.md); [11:4](../11/04.md), [8-9](../11/08.md); [49:7](../49/07.md). It may be necessary to translate this term in different ways, depending on the context. If the pronoun “you” is used here in your translation, it should be plural. Alternate translation: [disperse you] or [cause them to be spread out]

Jacob’s prophecy in [verse 7](../49/07.md) came true many years later: the tribe of Simeon was absorbed by the tribe of Judah ([Joshua 19:1](../../jos/19/01.md)), and the tribe of Levi never had its own territory, but rather lived in cities scattered throughout the other tribes of Israel ([Joshua 21:1–42](../../jos/21/01.md)). You could put this information in a footnote. Alternate translation: [throughout the descendants of Israel]

text: Judah, your brothers shall praise you. Your hand shall be on the necks of your enemies; your father’s sons shall bow down to you.

translation_challenges.note: In the Hebrew text, the pronoun **you** is emphatic, and it has an emphatic position in the sentence. Consider what is the best way to communicate that emphasis in your language. Alternate translation: [Judah, you are the one whom your brothers will praise] or [Judah, you and your descendants will be highly praised by your brothers and their descendants]

Consider what is the best way to translate this Hebrew idiom in your language. Also, if your translation includes Judah’s descendants in the previous sentence, make sure that the pronouns **your** and **you** are plural in this sentence. Alternate translation: [You will be victorious over] or [You will defeat]
Alternate translation: [those who are against you] or [your adversaries]
Make sure that your translation of **your father** refers to Jacob. Alternate translation: [Your brothers]

text: Judah is a young lion—my son, you return from the prey. Like a lion he crouches and lies down; like a lioness, who dares to rouse him?

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Judah, you, my son, are like a powerful young lion that kills its prey and returns to its den]

Here in [verse 9](../49/09.md) Jacob switches to using third person references (“he, his, him”) for Judah. For some languages it is better to use second person references (“you, your”) throughout [verses 8-12](../49/08.md). Alternate translation: [You are like a lion that stretches out and lies down to rest after eating]

This sentence forms a parallelism with the previous sentence to emphasize Judah’s authority. Also, Jacob uses a rhetorical question here to emphasize the respect that people will have for Judah. Some languages must use a statement here instead. Alternate translation: [Yes, you are like a lion that no one dares to awaken] or [No one dares to disrespect that lion]

text: The scepter will not depart from Judah, nor the staff from between his feet, until Shiloh comes and the allegiance of the nations is his.

translation_challenges.note: A scepter, or a king’s staff, is a special, decorated rod that a king holds to symbolize his authority to rule the people who are under him. Alternate translation: [Judah, the authority to rule will always belong to you and your descendants]
This phrase forms a parallelism with the previous clause and emphasizes the authority that Judah and his descendants will have.

Jacob is probably prophesying here about the coming of the Messiah/Christ. This fits with the fact that Jesus was a descendant of the tribe of Judah and is now ruling as the true King over heaven and earth. You could put some of that information in a footnote. Alternate translation: [until the highest king arrives] or [until the One whom the scepter belongs to comes]
Alternate translation: [and the nations of the earth obey him] or [and all people obey him] or [All people will obey him]

text: He ties his donkey to the vine, his colt to the choicest branch. He washes his garments in wine, his robes in the blood of grapes.

translation_challenges.note: In [verse 11](../49/11.md), the pronouns “he” and **his** refer to Judah and his descendants. To make that clear, you could make that explicit here and then use plural pronouns “they” and “their” throughout the verse. Or if you are using the second person throughout this section, you could say, “You and your descendants …” and use plural pronouns “you” and “your” after that. Alternate translation: [Judah and his descendants]

The author assumes that readers will know that in Jacob’s culture grapevines were valuable plants. Unless a person was very rich, he would never tether a donkey to his grapevines, because the donkey would eat the valuable fruit and the vines. If necessary, you could make some of that information explicit in your translation. Alternate translation: [He will be so rich that he will tie his donkey to his grapevines and let it eat the valuable fruit]
This clause forms a parallelism with the previous one to emphasize how wealthy Judah and his descendants will be.

This sentence is another parallelism that emphasizes how wealthy Judah and his descendants will be. The phrase **blood of grapes** is an idiom that refers to red wine made from the juice of grapes. Alternate translation: [They will still have so much wine from other vines that you could even use the wine like water to wash your robes and other clothes]

text: His eyes are darker than wine, and his teeth are whiter than milk.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [Their eyes] or [You will be so blessed that your eyes]

The Hebrew text is ambiguous here. It could mean: (1) “will be bright from drinking abundant wine,” or (2) “will be darker than wine,” In both interpretations the emphasis is that Judah’s descendants will be blessed with an abundance of the best foods, including wine and milk, which are examples of the most valuable foods that were produced in the land.

The Hebrew text is ambiguous here. It could mean: (1) “and their/your teeth will be white from drinking abundant milk.” or (2) “and their/your teeth will be whiter than milk.” Make sure that the way you translate this phrase fits with the interpretation you used for the first part of this verse.

text: Zebulun shall dwell by the seashore and become a harbor for ships; his border shall extend to Sidon.

translation_challenges.note: Throughout this chapter, decide whether it is best in your language to use third person or second person when Jacob refers to each of his sons (and their descendants). Alternate translation: [As for Zebulun, he and his descendants]
Alternate translation: [will live at the coast]

This clause forms a parallelism with the previous clause to emphasize where Zebulun and his descendants will live. Alternate translation: [yes, they will settle at a harbor for ships] or [where there will be a safe place for ships to load and unload their cargo]
Alternate translation: [all the way up to the city of Sidon]
Consider whether or not it is better in your language to begin a new sentence here. Alternate translation: [Their territory will extend]

text: Issachar is a strong donkey, lying down between the sheepfolds.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [As for Issachar, he and his descendants]
Alternate translation: [lying down resting]

The Hebrew text is ambiguous here. It could mean: (1) “between two saddlebags/loads.” or (2) “between the two parts of a sheep pen.” Both interpretations imply that the donkey is lying down to rest after it worked hard.

text: He saw that his resting place was good and that his land was pleasant, so he bent his shoulder to the burden and submitted to labor as a servant.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [They will have a good place to live, in a enjoyable land]
Consider what is the best way to translate this Hebrew idiom in your language. Alternate translation: [However, you will also have to exert yourselves] or [But you will work hard]
Alternate translation: [to carry heavy loads]
Alternate translation: [In fact, you will be forced to be slaves] or [They will have to work very hard for others as slaves] or [and people will force you to be their slaves]

text: Dan shall provide justice for his people as one of the tribes of Israel.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [As for Dan, he and his descendants]
Alternate translation: [will govern their own people group]
Alternate translation: [just as the other tribes of Israel govern their own people]

text: He will be a snake by the road, a viper in the path that bites the horse’s heels so that its rider tumbles backward.

translation_challenges.note: Be consistent with your choice of third person or second person (singular or plural) references to Dan (and his descendants) throughout [verses 16](../49/16.md) and [17](../49/17.md). Alternate translation: [They]
Alternate translation: [will be cunning like a poisonous snake lying beside a road]
Alternate translation: [so that it rears up and the rider falls off backward to the ground] or [… is thrown off the horse and defeated]

text: I await Your salvation, O LORD.

translation_challenges.note: Make sure it is clear in your translation that Jacob is talking to God in [verse 18](../49/18.md), not Dan any more.

text: Gad will be attacked by raiders, but he will attack their heels.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [a group of robbers will attack him and his descendants] or [you and your descendants will be attacked by enemies]
Make sure it is clear in your translation who is being referred to at each point in this sentence. Alternate translation: [but they will hunt them down and defeat them]

text: Asher’s food will be rich; he shall provide royal delicacies.

translation_challenges.note: Here the word **bread** refers to food in general and **fat** refers to the best kinds of food. Alternate translation: [Asher and his descendants will produce rich food] or [Asher, you and your descendants will be wealthy and produce the finest food]
Alternate translation: [and he will even supply food that is fancy enough for a king] or [In fact, they will supply fine foods that are fit for kings to eat]

text: Naphtali is a doe set free that bears beautiful fawns.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [As for Naphtali, he and his descendants]
This image pictures a deer that swiftly runs away after being released from captivity. Alternate translation: [will be swift like a doe] or [will be warriors who are swift like a deer]
Alternate translation: [that is set free] or [that has been released to run freely] or [that is free to go wherever it wants]

The Hebrew text is ambiguous here. It could mean: (1) “He/They/You will also speak eloquently.” or “They/You will also be gifted/excellent speakers/negotiators.” or (2) “and that bears/has beautiful/healthy fawns.” or “He/They/You will have beautiful children.” If you made Naphtali’s descendants explicit at the beginning of this verse, make sure you use a plural pronoun (“they” or “you”) here.

text: Joseph is a fruitful vine—a fruitful vine by a spring, whose branches scale the wall.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [As for Joseph, he and his descendants]

The same phrase is repeated here to emphasize how prosperous and productive Joseph (and his descendants) will be. Instead of saying the same phrase twice, many translations combine the two phrases and form one clause that communicates the emphasis in a different way. Do what is accurate and natural in your language. Alternate translation: [will be like the branch of a fruitful tree, yes, like a fruitful tree] or [will be very successful and flourish like a fruitful branch of a vine] or [will be very fruitful like the fruit on a fruitful vine]
Alternate translation: [that is planted next to a spring of water]

This phrase probably continues the word picture of the fruitful vine that symbolizes how prosperous and numerous Joseph and his descendants will be. Consider what is the best way to translate this word picture in your language. Alternate translation: [with branches extending] or [with branches full of fruit that extend]
Alternate translation: [over a surrounding wall]

text: The archers attacked him with bitterness; they aimed at him in hostility.

translation_challenges.note: Be consistent with your choice of third person or second person (singular or plural) references to Joseph (and his descendants) throughout [verses 22-26](../49/22.md). Alternate translation: [Skillful bowmen will fiercely attack them and their descendants] or [Enemy soldiers will …] or [Your enemies will …]
Alternate translation: [and shoot arrows at them]
Alternate translation: [and treat them hatefully] or [and try to destroy them]

text: Yet he steadied his bow, and his strong arms were tempered by the hands of the Mighty One of Jacob, in the name of the Shepherd, the Rock of Israel,

translation_challenges.note: Make sure that the way you translate **his** in this verse fits with whether you use second or third person (singular or plural) to refer to Joseph (and his descendants) in [verses 22-26](../49/22.md). Alternate translation: [But as they fight back, you will hold your bows steady] or [… you will use your bows well]
Alternate translation: [and their powerful arms will stay agile]
Consider what is the best way to translate this idiom in your language. Alternate translation: [because of the power]

For some languages, it is clearer or more natural to change the order of the phrases in this verse and say, “But the Mighty/Powerful God whom I worship/serve will keep you strong and help you use your bows/weapons well/effectively as you fight back.” Alternate translation: [of the Powerful God whom I worship] or [that the Powerful God of Jacob gives you]

A shepherd takes care of his sheep and provides for all of their needs. In the same way God takes care of his people and provides for all of their needs. See [Psalm 23](../../psa/023/001.md) which also talks about God as our Shepherd. You could put some of that information in a footnote. Alternate translation: [He takes care of his people the way that a shepherd takes care of his sheep]

In [verses 24](../49/24.md) and [25](../49/25.md), several different titles are used to refer to Yahweh, the only true God. Make sure that your translation of these verses does not sound like there is more than one God. Also make sure it is clear in your translation or in a footnote that Jacob is referring to himself in this verse as Jacob and Israel.

text: by the God of your father who helps you, and by the Almighty who blesses you, with blessings of the heavens above, with blessings of the depths below, with blessings of the breasts and womb.

translation_challenges.note: Alternate translation: [That power is from]
Alternate translation: [the God who has always taken care of me, your father. He will also help you and your descendants]

For some languages it may be clearer or more natural to change the order of some of the clauses in the first half of this verse and say, “That strength/power comes from the God who has always taken care of me, your father. He is the all-powerful God who will help you and your descendants and bless you all.” Also, compare how you translated “God Almighty” in Genesis [48:3](../48/03.md). Alternate translation: [He is the all-powerful God, who will bless you all]
Alternate translation: [He will provide you with rain from the sky]
This phrase refers to water that comes from under the ground and supplies springs, wells, and rivers. Alternate translation: [and bless you with water from under the ground]
Consider what is the best way to translate this metonymy in your language. Alternate translation: [May your wives bear many children and your animals bear many young]

text: The blessings of your father have surpassed the blessings of the ancient mountains and the bounty of the everlasting hills. May they rest on the head of Joseph, on the brow of the prince of his brothers.

translation_challenges.note: The Hebrew text is ambiguous here. It could mean: (1) “God has blessed me your father more than he blessed my ancestors,” or (2) “The blessings your father is blessing you with are greater than the blessings my ancestors blessed me with,” or (3) “The blessings of your father have surpassed the blessings/riches of the ancient mountains,” The third interpretation is based on the Greek Septuagint, which interprets the Hebrew word for **ancestors** as “mountains” (which has a similar spelling in Hebrew).

The meaning of the Hebrew text is uncertain here. It could mean: (1) “He has blessed me with riches that are greater than the riches that come from” or (2) “My blessings are so great that they extend to the farthest boundaries/limits of.”

The words **head** and **top of the head** refer to Joseph and are connected with the custom of laying hands on the head of the person being blessed. Alternate translation: [May God also give those blessings to you Joseph, as] or [I pray that God will abundantly bless you too, Joseph, since you are]

The expression **the one consecrated from** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the one God consecrated from among] or [the one whom God chose to set apart and honor among]

It could mean: (1) “Atad’s threshing floor/place,” or “a place owned by a man named Atad where people separated grain from chaff,” or (2) “the threshing floor/place near the city/town of Atad,” or “Goren Ha-Atad,” or (3) “the grain/wheat threshing place that was surrounded by thornbushes,” The Hebrew word “atad” means “thorns,” but most Bible scholars think it refers here to the name of a person or city.
